mission_description: The Festival and Parade honors the early Chinese pioneers of the Sierra.

name: Constitution Day Parade
mission_description: Nevada City’s Constitution Day Parade, a local tradition since 1967, is reported to be the oldest and largest Constitution observance in western America.   The parade through the downtown historic district includes marching bands, floats, antique autos, equestrians, politicians and the perennial crowd favorites the Famous Marching Presidents of Nevada City.

name: Cornish Christmas
mission_description: Cornish Christmas started in 1967 as a way to preserve Grass Valley’s Cornish heritage and holiday traditions. Mill and West Main Streets are closed to motorized traffic and filled with the sights and sounds of an old fashioned Christmas; carolers, jugglers, musicians, magicians, the Grass Valley Cornish Carol Choir, Tommyknocker Cloggers and of course, Santa Claus. Enjoy delicious food and drink while perusing handmade arts and crafts from artists throughout California.

name: Craw Thaw Music Festival
mission_description: A FREE New Orleans inspired spring event, the TRUCKEE CRAW THAW Music Festival will bring a diverse lineup of American roots inspired musicians, Cajun cuisine and family fun to historic downtown Truckee, California

name: Cruzin' in the Pines Car Show
mission_description: One of the best classic car shows in Northern California.

name: Draft Horse Classic
mission_description: The Classic has grown to become the premier Draft Horse show in the western United States, and features six majestic performances, breathtaking competitions and entertainment in between classes.

name: Earth's Treasures Gem & Mineral Show
mission_description: Check out the gem and mineral collections, visit the booths of the numerous vendors, bid on minerals and rocks at a silent auction, watch local artisans at work, and see the demonstrations. This show is a great place to meet other enthusiasts, buy supplies, and experience everything the rock and mineral hobby has to offer.

name: Fall Colors Open Studio Tour  (host:Center for the Arts)
mission_description: The Center for the Arts, with support from the Nevada County Arts Council, presents the Fall Colors Open Studio Tour.  Over 70 local artists welcome the public to 47 studios and art galleries during a free tour spanning two weekends in October.

name: Fathers Day Bluegrass Festival
mission_description: California Bluegrass Association presents a legendary bluegrass, old time, and gospel music festival over four days in June.

name: First Friday Art Walk
mission_description: The First Friday Art Walk is a celebration of Nevada City’s diverse mix of galleries, artisan boutiques, retail shops, wine tasting rooms, restaurants, as well as our wonderfully artistic and creative community.

name: Foothills Celebration
mission_description: The Foothills Celebration is just the therapy you’ll need for a late winter weekend.  The wineries and restaurants are all paired with local downtown Grass Valley merchants who open their stores for this unique wine and food tasting affair.

name: Grass Valley Car Show
mission_description: Travel back in time and experience American nostalgia at its best. See approximately 300 of the finest custom, vintage and antique cars and trucks in all of Northern California; in a city that honors its historic past and embraces its wonderful future: Historic Downtown Grass Valley.

name: Grass Valley Farmers Market
mission_description: The Grass Valley Thursday Night Markets are a wonderful community event that includes a certified Farmer’s Market and a whole lot more including arts, crafts, food, and the ever popular FREE Summer Concert Series.

name: Grass Valley Old West Antique Show
mission_description: The annual Old West Antiques Show provides the opportunity to view and purchase world class merchandise from a legendary list of dealers in all collecting categories, including museum quality Antique Firearms, Native American items, Western & Cowboy Memorabilia, Advertising, Coin Operated & Gambling, Saloon & General Store, Paintings, Bronzes, Lamps, Gas & Oil, Jewelry, Furniture and more!

name: Holidays at the Empire Mine
mission_description: Celebrate the holidays early 1900s’ style at Holidays at Empire Mine.  With old fashioned decorations, lavish period costumes, and festive live music, Empire Cottage will be brimming with good cheer. Docents will share insights about Empire’s glory days when it ranked as one of the most prosperous hard-rock gold mines in North American history

name: Mardis Gras Parade
mission_description: The 27th anniversary of Nevada City’s annual Mardi Gras Celebration is set to happen on Sunday, February 17, 2019. The annual event, hosted by the Nevada City Chamber of Commerce, features a colorful & festive parade & street faire throughout the streets of historic downtown Nevada City.

name: Miners Picnic
mission_description: The annual Miners Picnic is a summer celebration of our colorful, gold mining history. The first Miners Picnic was held in 1895 to raise money for miners’ widows and orphans, as well as injured and out of work miners. Today, it’s an action packed day of fun, food, gold history, and lasting memories.

name: Music in the Mountains Sierra Brewfest
mission_description: A unique, unlimited microbrew tasting experience. Sample 60+ microbrews. There is a no host wine bar for those who would prefer wine over beer, and delicious food from some of the best local food trucks and restaurants.

name: Music in the Mountains Summer Fest
mission_description: For more than 37 years, Music in the Mountains  SummerFest has been Northern California’s premier summer concert series, featuring exciting outdoor performances and sophisticated chamber concerts, demonstrating that classical music, performed by a world class orchestra and chorus, can transform lives and communities.

name: Nevada City Craft Fair
mission_description: Nevada City Craft Fair is a juried exhibition of makers curated in the aesthetics of the modern rustic lifestyle that NCCF embodies. Hip, sustainable, yet innovative, represents the best of the region in our bi annual craft fair held at the historic Miners Foundry in downtown Nevada City.

name: Nevada City Farmers Market
mission_description: Each Saturday from June to November more than 30 vendors join a group of loyal volunteers to create a vibrant community event on Union Street in downtown Nevada City.

name: Nevada City Film Festival
mission_description: NCFF screens almost 100 films, including comedies, dramas, documentaries, animation, and international shorts, in a variety of historic locations in downtown Nevada City. By combining creative programming of short and full length films, enthusiastic audiences and a truly festive environment, NCFF has become known as one of the most innovative, fun and artist friendly events on the film festival circuit.

name: Nevada City Summer Nights
mission_description: The Summer Nights in Nevada City celebration, a street festival of art and music, has been an annual tradition in this quaint, scenic, historic (and sometimes quirky) community, for close to 30 years. This free event takes place on three Wednesday evenings in July, when  Nevada City’s landmark historic district is closed to motorized traffic and filled with arts, crafts, classic cars, food, drink and music. Leading Sierra foothills musicians perform on outdoor stages throughout the downtown area.

name: Nevada County Certified Growers Market
mission_description: Nevada County's original certified market, bringing growers and the community together since 1980.

name: Nevada County Fair
mission_description: Five days of excitement and fun for Fair goers of all ages. Enjoy live entertainment, delicious food, carnival rides, animals, and exhibits in a community friendly environment and at affordable family prices!

name: New Years Eve Light Parade & Fireworks
mission_description: Let's ring in the New Year in mountain fashion. This free fun event is for intermediate skiers and riders ages 10 or older who can ski or ride unassisted in the dark on the Snowbird run. Come early to secure a spot in the parade. If you are wanting to spectate the event, join us at the bar for a warm drink. The New Year’s Fireworks show will follow the Light Parade.

name: Nugget Fringe Theater Festival
mission_description: An eclectic mix of cutting edge performances from around the world

name: Penn Valley Hometown Fall Festival
mission_description: The Penn Valley Hometown Fall Festival is an old fashioned family fun event where kids can play games and end explore the pumpkin patch while adults enjoy food demonstrations, brats and beer, music, local wineries, and vendors.

name: Penn Valley Rodeo
mission_description: PVCRA produces quality family entertainment in the western tradition with two nights of pro rodeo, Friday and Saturday.  Events include AMA sanctioned Mule & Donkey Show, the Doc Halstead Open Barrel Race series, and Summer Fun Gymkhana Buckle series.

name: Ridgestock Music & Sustainability Festival
mission_description: Ridgestock brings together residents & families with organizations, businesses, musicians, vendors and performers under the towering pines nestled in the Sierra  foothills, to educate and entertain. Ridgestock offers a wide array of vendors and informational speakers, alongside a lineup of great music on the grounds of the historic North Columbia Schoolhouse and Amphitheatre.

name: Secession Days
mission_description: On the first Sunday of June, Rough and Ready celebrates Secession Days with a special Chili Cookoff.  Guests can taste and vote for their favorite chili along with the judges.   The Original Saga of Rough and Ready melodrama, Blacksmith demonstrations in the historic Fippin Blacksmith Shop, a variety of vendors and crafters, music, additional food options from the local Community Hall and Firefighter's Association, raffles, souvenir sales, water slide and bounce house for the kids...it's fun for the whole family!

name: Sierra BrewFest
mission_description: A unique, unlimited microbrew tasting experience. Sample over 60 microbrews and a no host wine bar for those who would prefer wine over beer!  This year features even more delicious food from some of the best local food trucks and restaurants.

name: Sierra Poetry Festival
mission_description: In addition to its mainstage event, Sierra Poetry Festival marks National Poetry Month from the rolling foothills of California’s Gold Country to the rugged High Sierra, bringing our rich literary community together to celebrate the spoken word and reach out to brand new audiences in fresh ways. Readings, workshops, music, an activity fair for all ages and youth performances will be preceded by a month of pre festival pop-up poetry events.

name: Sierra Storytelling Festival
mission_description: Known as the Queen of Storytelling Festivals, our festival brings a lineup of talented, nationally recognized storytellers to the Schoolhouse stages. People have told stories since the beginning of time and our storytellers keep the tradition alive, voicing the narratives of life, our histories and traditions, our reasons for living, our hopes and dreams.

name: Mothers Day Springtime Event at Empire Mine
mission_description: Enjoy springtime fountains, rose gardens and lavish period costumes. Stroll through beautiful Empire Cottage and meet docents portraying the colorful characters who shaped our local, gold mine history. The old Mineyard will be full of activity, much the way it was in Empire’s heydays of gold, grit and glory.

name: St. Piran's Day Festival
mission_description: Every year Grass Valley captures some fun with its annual St. Piran’s Day pasty tossing contest. The rain or shine event, which celebrates the Cornish immigrants who settled around the gold mines, is fun for adults, children and especially dogs.

name: Strawberry Music Festival
mission_description: The Strawberry Music Festival presents the gold standard in main stage entertainment, intimate side stage performances, top notch children’s programming, workshops and activities for the whole family, and some of the nicest people you will ever meet. Programs like the Breakfast Club and the Band Scramble, live broadcasts by Hog Ranch Radio, and Strawberry’s legendary camp jam culture are what makes this your festival.

name: Summer Music Series
mission_description: Every Wednesday from June 20 to August 29, TDRPD hosts a community gathering with great music in the amphitheater located at Truckee Regional Park.

name: The Childrens’ Festival
mission_description: The Children’s Festival has become one of the premiere summer events for children, with over 2000 children and adults attending. All who attend leave with fond memories and many of the children who attended in the 1970’s and 80’s are now returning with their own children. A very special event that brings the community together to celebrate the magic of imagination.

name: Truckee Rodeo
mission_description: The Truckee Professional Rodeo Association strives to enrich our community by keeping the western heritage of our town alive and by giving back to other local organizations each year.

name: Truckee Thursdays
mission_description: Truckee Thursdays is a feel good event that beckons the community to enjoy some exuberant downtown summertime energy. Offering a stage with live music; a food court with an eclectic selection of eats; children’s activities; a beer garden; and a wide variety of artisan vendors.  In addition, attendees will find sidewalk sales and other activities hosted by downtown merchants.

name: Victorian Christmas
mission_description: The enticing aromas of roasted chestnuts and hearty holiday foods fill the air, along with cries of street vendors hawking their wares and lamp lit streets filled to overflowing with handcrafted candy, jewelry, pottery, perfume, dolls, and over 100 different items in all.  This annual, family tradition takes place 2nd Wednesday evenings and 3rd Sunday afternoons in December and features holiday activities for all ages.

name: Wild & Scenic Environmental Film Festival
mission_description: One of the nation’s premier environmental and adventure film festivals, the 17th annual event will feature films that combine stellar filmmaking, beautiful cinematography and first-rate storytelling to inform, inspire and ignite solutions and possibilities to restore the earth. Each year, the Wild & Scenic Film Festival draws top filmmakers, celebrities, leading activists, social innovators and well-known world adventurers for film, music, workshops, celebrations, and inspiration.

name: The Camelot Gallery
mission_description: A beautiful fine art gallery nestled in the foothills of the Sierras.

name: Art Obsessions
mission_description: Art Obsessions officially opened its door in June 2011 in Truckee's Historic Downtown District. The gallery quickly gained recognition as a premiere source for the works of renowned regional and international artists and established itself as a primary source for limited edition prints. The gallery also features a superior collection of modern and traditional sculpture. Art Obsessions is known as a "must see" stop in Truckee's Historic Downtown District.

name: Art Truckee
mission_description: Art Gallery, Performance and Event Venue and Wine Bar

name: Art Works Gallery Co-op
mission_description: Located in the historic gold mining town of Grass Valley, California, the gallery is at the center of a vibrant visual and performing arts community.  Over 30 juried visual artists cooperate in presenting their work in this 19th century building.  The work includes ceramic, glass, jewelry, painting, woodturning, furniture, fiber art, metal, mosaic, mixed media, photography, and sculpture.

name: Artists Studio in the Foothills (ASIF)
mission_description: The Artists Studio in the Foothills (ASiF) is a 4000 sq. ft., fully-equipped studio art center. In 2008 ASiF opened its doors with a mission to nurture the creative spirit of the community, offer a professional studio atmosphere and creative home for visual artists by providing a place where are can be made, displayed and appreciated.  The center offers classes and workshops in a variety of media for all ages, private and shared studio space for working artists, and a gallery to promote local and visiting artists.

name: Atelier
mission_description: Founded in 2015, Atelier offers a collection of hand-sourced 2D prints, paintings and designer art wares and an exclusive collection of artist supplies and materials.  Atelier strives to be the creative hub of the local art community by hosting workshops taught by the area’s most sought after artists, illustrators, designers, weavers, knitters, painters and more who share the vision to create always and inspire all.

name: Bolam Gallery
mission_description: The Bolam Gallery was established in 2000 to bring world class fine art to the north shore of lake Tahoe. We represent the finest local and nationally acclaimed artists, specializing in traditional western subject matter reimagined with a modern viewpoint.

name: BriarPatch Art Gallery and Amphitheater
mission_description: BriarPatch Food Co-op offers art exhibit space for the enjoyment of our customers and to promote local art.

name: Center for the Arts Gallery
mission_description: This aesthetically pleasing display space for the visual arts features shows by local, regional, and international artists. The gallery also serves as an intimate venue for meetings, artist receptions, literary and dramatic readings. The space includes a concessions area and no-host bar.

name: EJ Gallery
mission_description: A workshop space that showcases the creativity of its member artists. You'll find sculpture, jewelry, works on paper, fine art prints, antiquities, coins, mobiles, collage, mixed media, miniatures and music. The gallery also features the work of well known artists such as Picasso, Miro, Dali, Chagall and Matisse. There's always something new and interesting waiting just for you!

name: Ellu Gallery
mission_description: Ellu Gallery is a 2,200 sq. ft. artist owned collaborative gallery and event space. Ellu provides custom staging, commercial art lease programs and rents the gallery space for truly unique events and custom shows. Both private and public events are available. Hand selected artists versed in large scale one of a kind paintings and sculptures are featured at Ellu. Life is Art. Ellu Gallery breaks the old paradigm into a timeless lucid dream with an ever expanding collection from Zen surrealism, abstract, Expressionism, blown glass, wood sculpture, to hand made guitars.

name: Elixart Herbal Lounge & Gallery
mission_description: Elixart is an herbal elixir lounge and visionary art gallery offering the highest integrity and highest vibration ingredients throughout our menu of mood-enhancing elixir drinks, kava, tea, and other exotics; raw food, and premium organic products.

name: Emigrant Trail Museum
mission_description: The Emigrant Trail Museum contains exhibits about the cultural history of the area, including local Native Americans, the Donner Party, and building of the First Transcontinental Railroad.

name: Firehouse No.1
mission_description: Completed in the Spring of 1861, this firehouse was home to Nevada Hose Company No.1 from 1861 to 1938. During those nearly 80 years, horse -drawn fire wagons, handcarts and “modern” motorized fire engines rolled out the doors.

name: Gallery 5830’
mission_description: Gallery 5830′ is a creative portal, featuring an eclectic mix of artwork and furniture, hand crafted by artists in the local community and neighboring regions. Through our mission to connect clients with the creative community, Gallery 5830’ offers a selection of in house artwork for sale on consignment. Gallery 5830’ also facilitates artist/ client commissions that emphasize a collaborative vision, site-specific designs and refined old-world craftsmanship.

name: Grass Roots Antique Tool Museum
mission_description: Our specialty is one-of-a-kind custom installations designed virtually from photos of your home, office or business.

name: St. Joseph Cultural Center
mission_description: St. Joseph's Cultural Center is a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving a historic landmark for cultural activities in the community. It is owned and operated by the Historic Mount St. Mary's Preservation Committee.

name: JoAnne’s Stained Glass & Gallery
mission_description: JoAnne's Stained Glass Gallery in historic downtown Truckee is filled with beautiful stained glass stars, snowflakes and crystals. JoAnne's specializes in stained glass, leaded and beveled glass, sandblasted etched glass and fused art glass. Most of the stained glass and etched pieces are designed by JoAnne and fabricated in JoAnne's Truckee studio.

name: Joseph Research Cabin
mission_description: Truckee Donner Historical Society was founded July 24, 1968 to preserve the history of the Truckee Donner area. Besides maintaining the historic Joseph Research Cabin (the Gateway Cabin), the Society is also responsible for operating the Old Jail Museum which was built in 1875.  The Society maintains the Community Memorial Garden including the Memorial Arch behind the Old Jail Museum, the Donner  Cross, and Schaffer Cemetery.

name: Kitkitdizzi
mission_description: Both natives of the tiny gold rush town of Nevada City, we became friends at age five and have been partners ever since. We have been blessed to inherit a super rad shop in an old drugstore on the main street in our lovely little town. We have vowed to sell only what we love: salt of the earth, mountain forest loving, unless desert escaping, vintage valuing, artisan constructed excellence without snobby artifice, all with California gold rush swagger.

name: LeeAnn Brook Gallery
mission_description: Opened in July 2015, LeeAnn Brook Fine Art is one of the first artist-owned gallery and on site studio in Nevada County, California. Located at 231 Broad St, in the heart of historic downtown Nevada City, the gallery also incorporates the working studio of LeeAnn Brook, where visitors can see paintings in progress and discuss the art with the artist firsthand.

name: Lilly Vigil Gallery
mission_description: Lilly Vigil Gallery is located within the heart of the Sierra Nevada in beautiful downtown Nevada City, California. Since 1985, Vigil's is recognized for unparalleled quality of artistic and cultural treasures, focusing on fine Native American art. The gallery also specializes in originals, graphics, sculptors and exquisite jewelry from local, regional, and national artists.

name: Lorien Powers Studio Jewelry
mission_description: Lorien Powers is an artist who specializes in creating industrial and contemporary style jewelry. Lorien prefers to work with gold, silver, natural gems, and minerals. Known for the decorative features of her work, she employs a wide variety of techniques, including roller printing, cold connecting, riveting, fabricating and forging. She draws inspiration for her jewelry from many different sources, some from nature, some from music (Phish in particular), some from industrial environments.

name: Lucchesi Vineyards Tasting Room
mission_description: The Lucchesi Tasting Room is open from 11:00 am until the party's over, every day except Easter, Christmas, and Thanksgiving. Our summer hours are extended for special events, please call us for more information.

name: Morrison Hotel Gallery
mission_description: Morrison Hotel Gallery is the leader in Fine art music photography. With galleries in New York, Los Angeles and Maui our gallery represents over 130 of the best music photographers and artists. From the jazz photography of Billy Holiday, Miles Davis and the Blue Note collection to The Beatles, Rolling Stones and Bruce Springsteen to the contemporary artists of today, Morrison Hotel Gallery has every print for every taste in music.

name: Mountain Arts Collective
mission_description: Located at the Train Depot in historic Downtown Truckee, Mountain Arts Collective began in 2017, with three local artists who wanted to showcase quality art by individuals closely connected to the community. Our goal is to create a welcoming space that will attract locals and visitors with high end statement pieces, more affordable arts & gifts, and everything in between.

name: Mountain Forge
mission_description: Hand forged iron work.

name: Narrow Gauge Railroad Museum
mission_description: Located in Nevada City, California, the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad and Transportation Museum is dedicated to the preservation of local transportation history and artifacts from the narrow gauge railroad era. Visitors are offered a docent led historical tour of the museum, rail yard, and restoration shop. There is no admission charge.

name: Nevada City Picture Framing
mission_description: Our mission is to provide you, the customer, with an enjoyable full spectrum experience at our shop, whether in custom framing, art restoration, or fine art acquisition. Our friendly staff of experts is always ready to help you create a one of a kind, unique frame design. Stop by our gallery for art and gifts!

name: North Star House
mission_description: Our mission is to rehabilitate and transform the Historic North Star House into a premier cultural event center and to promote Nevada County’s legacy by fostering local arts, letters and sciences.

name: North Star Power House & Pelton Wheel Museum
mission_description: The North Star Mining Museum, a part of the Nevada County Historical Society, is one of the gems of Nevada County and exists not only to preserve and protect our area’s mining heritage but also educates and informs people not only about the mining process, but also about the impact the industry had upon the humanity of the people who built the mines and those who toiled there during their operation.

name: Old Jail Museum
mission_description: Truckee’s historic jail museum is one of only a few surviving 19th-century jailhouses of its kind in the West and one of the few remaining original buildings in Truckee. The old Bastille was used continuously from 1875 until May 1964, and ably withstood the many fires that swept the town in its early days.  Although jails are usually sturdy, Truckee’s is a virtual strongbox. The original building consisted of just the lower level, constructed of native stone. The walls are 32-inches thick at the lower level, with no windows unless one counts the small vents for each cell, which are set with irregular rows of two-inch steel bars. The ceilings are plate steel, insulated with dirt, and lined with narrow gauge railroad tracks. All doors are riveted steel, weighing an estimated 200 pounds each.

name: Osborn Woods Gallery
mission_description: The Miners Foundry Cultural Center is a living historic treasure serving Nevada County as a cultural arts and community events center.  More than a venue, the nonprofit’s mission is to preserve, enhance and utilize the historic Miners Foundry for cultural, educational and social activities in Nevada County.

name: Riverside Studios
mission_description: Riverside Studios mission is to cultivate artistic growth in the Truckee Community while handcrafting one of a kind artistic goods, creating a unique shopping experience for both locals and tourists alike. From paintings to pottery, from leather goods to jewelry and metal sculpture there is something for everyone.

name: Searls Historical Library  (NC Historical Society)
mission_description: The Searls Historical Library is the archive of the Nevada County Historical Society.  Established in 1973, the Searls Library has become one of the premier libraries of materials on the area's history, people and mines which contributed to the development of this county.

name: Sierra Color Studio
mission_description: Photographer and Truckee local Esteban Peralta has been taking photos since high school but recently decided to make a career out of his passion. Esteban feels the business name Sierra Color Studio appropriate as he lives in the Sierra Mountains and most of his photos are taken here.

name: Spirithouse Import Gallery
mission_description: Featuring a fairly traded, personally chosen collection of fine artisan jewelry, clothing and home decor, from the Hearts and Hands of Southeast Asia

name: Starr Winery Tasting Room
mission_description: Sierra Starr Vineyard and Winery is a small vineyard and winery in the Sierra Foothills AVA. Owned and operated by the Starr Family, Phil and Anne since 1995 and their son Jackson since 2005.

name: Swan Levine House & Printmaking Studio
mission_description: The Swan Levine House plays significantly into the history of Nevada County. The fine art of Printmaking is illustrated by the extensive collection of art throughout the house.

name: The Artist Workshop
mission_description: We offer Pottery, Candle Making, Paint & Sips, Wood Signs, DIY Bags and Pillows and Canvas Art, we also have a great retail section with art supplies. We are a place to come to make gifts, unique pieces for your home or just a place to come and get crafty.

name: The Carmel Gallery
mission_description: If you believe in the visual pleasure of beauty, and that enhancing your environment enhances your life, we invite you to explore our diverse collection of stunning fine art photographs that celebrate the enduring beauty of our world. International award winning fine art photographers Olof and Elizabeth Carmel personally print, sign and number each of their limited edition fine art prints.

name: The Curious Forge
mission_description: Our mission is to provide access to traditional and advanced tools, a large space and a variety of skill sets in a collaborative and innovative environment that enables the members to create what matters to them.

name: The Louvre Framing, Restoration and Gallery
mission_description: Locally owned and operated, we provide top quality custom framing and art restoration. While you're in, visit our on-site gallery.

name: Truckee Railroad Museum
mission_description: Truckee Railroad Museum is located next to the historic railroad station in downtown Truckee. This adds historical significance to the area, as the caboose is from the Southern Pacific Railroad and was used in the area. Paint for the caboose matches the original SP paint scheme. Inside the museum are stories, pictures, recreations, and railroad artifacts depicting the impact of railroads in the formation and development of Truckee. The First Transcontinental Railroad, Logging Railroads, and Tourism by Rail all played an important part in Truckee’s history.

name: Truckee Tahoe Airport District (Art at the Airport)
mission_description: Since 1958, the Truckee Tahoe Airport District has been providing a high quality, safe facility for pilots, visitors and the community. Nestled in the Sierra Nevada mountain range at an elevation of 5,900 ft., twelve miles from Lake Tahoe, we promise one of the most scenic flight and visiting experiences in the world. We are proud of our pilot safety and community programs, state of the art energy saving facilities and top notch staff and leadership. We are committed to offering the best small, mountain airport in the Country.

name: West Wind
mission_description: A Garden Sanctuary Store featuring local artists Deborah Bridges, Jerrianne Van Dyk, Meg Black Smith, Jerry Delong and many others.

name: Western SkiSport Museum
mission_description: The Western SkiSport Museum was founded in 1969 by the Auburn Ski Club. Working with ski writer and historian William B. Berry, the Museum was developed as an exhibition of Western North American ski history. Today the Museum continues on a mission to collect, preserve and exhibit the history of winter ski sports in the western United States.

name: Wild Eye Pub
mission_description: Wild Eye Pub gives customers great food, inspired drinks, and attentive service in a comfortable, art-filled space; a perfect place to connect with others, nurture creative ideas, and nourish body and spirit.

name: Stucki Jewelers and Engravers
mission_description: Stucki Jewelers specializes in every aspect of fine jewelry. We have a qualified and caring sales staff to help you find the perfect gift for that special loved one or that special something you have always wanted.  We also check and clean your jewelry complimentary, and offer a full service, onsite repair shop for all your repair needs.  By supporting Stucki Jewelers you support us in giving back to our local community, as we continue to donate to more than 45 local organizations

name: Utopian Stone
mission_description: Nestled in the Sierra Nevada Foothills, Utopian Stone was founded in 1974 by G. Patrick Dyer and wife, Diane. We employ four master goldsmiths, plus a fifth, Dean Dussell, who works from his studio in Colorado. At Utopian Stone we specialize in high quality one of a kind work and customer commissions. Our favorite thing is to design for clients who have no idea what they want. As we do not reproduce our one of a kind creations, our customers challenge our designers who may want something similar to a one of a kind piece, but with its own unique personal flair

name: Nevada City Crystal and Glass
mission_description: Swarovski Crystal Living, Swarovski Jewelry, Anna Leece Jewelry, Art Glass, Home Decor, Barware, Custom-made Jewelry, Shopping.

name: Mooney Flat Hotel
address: In front of private home at 10885 Mooney Flat Rd, one mile north of Hwy 20
mission_description: Mooney Flat Hotel 1856-1958. Site of the first 3-story team & stage stop on the Henness Pass route to the Northern Mines and Comstock Lode. Built and operated by George and Veronica Schmidt. Served miners, travelers, and teamsters.

name: Nevada City High School Site
address: Near sidewalk, across from 626 Zion St, Nevada City
mission_description: Plaque dedicated by former students: Nevada City High School was located on this site from 1912-1952. This plaque was placed by former students as a lasting memorial to their high school. Note: After merger of Grass Valley and Nevada City high schools, Seven Hills School used the building as a junior high school. In 1973 the buildings were sold to the County of Nevada and eventually torn down. A charter school occupies the adjoining grounds.

name: Anthony House Site
address: East side of Pleasant Valley Rd next to dam spillway at Lake Wildwood
mission_description: Anthony House and Ranch. In 1849, a Mr. Anthony staked out 160 acres on the north side of Deer Creek on the road which would become part of the Marysville-Henness Pass-Virginia City trade route, and built a house and out-buildings. While further details about Mr. Anthony are unknown, the name Anthony House prevailed through a succession of owners. The property was up for sale in 1852 and purchased by Mr. S. P. French. By that time it was a flourishing stage stop, serving as a hotel, restaurant, livery stable and post office. The original house burned down in 1876 but was quickly rebuilt. Subsequent owners included William Henry Davey, Nevada County Supervisor 1908-1916 and later his son, Frank Davey. Stage stop and post office operations continued to 1906 when the post office was moved to Smartsville. Thereafter, declining traffic on the trade route led to farming and cattle raising as the main use of the property. By 1970 when Boise Cascade began development of this area, the property had fallen into disrepair and the house was burned down as a training exercise by the Penn Valley Fire Protection District. Construction of Anthony Dam here on Deer Creek submerged any remains of this historic site under Lake Wildwood.

name: Felix Gillet
address: Stone pillar by driveway at intersection of Nursery and Nihell Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Here lived and worked Felix Gillet, A Frenchman by birth, an American by adoption from 1871 to 1908 through whose vision and perseverance the horticulture of the world was enriched by the propagation and culture of walnuts, filberts, chestnuts, prunes. In commemoration of his work this tablet was set March 7, 1933 by the WomenÍs Civic Club of Nevada City, California.

name: Hartung House
mission_description: In August of 1888 Nevada and Emma (Schwartz) Hartung purchased about 220 acres bordering Pleasant Valley Rd. and Piper Lane in Pleasant Valley (now Penn Valley). At the time of purchase, a small house and a barn were on the property. These two structures likely were built in the early 1860s when the property was owned by James and Hannah Saxon. The first house, still standing in the 1930’s, had deteriorated and was razed. The well, located in the front porch of the house remains. The barn now extended on both ends, still exists. The Hartungs built the current house in 1889. Pear, apple and walnut crops became the primary means of support for the family. A few of the original pear trees remain. Nevada August Hartung was born in August 1853 on the shores of Webber Lake, California in a wagon train on the family's way west from Illinois. It is reported that Nevada's given name was the result of the parents’ awe at their first sight of the Sierra Nevada Mountains. He grew up on his father Adolph Hartung's farm at Kentucky Flat and married Emma Schwartz in 1880. By the time of their 1888 purchase of the property, the Hartungs had three children, Frank (b.1880), Herman (b. 1884) and Mamie (b. 1886). The Hartungs bought the farm from Samuel and Agnes Yeo (owners 1888-1888) and prior to that the property was owned by Joseph Peers (1886-1888) and the Saxons (ca.1860-1886). In 1849-1850, John Rose and William Reynolds operated a trading post and cattle corral, both thought to be located on what became the Hartung property. The current owner, Pete Brennan, acquired the property in 1971 and operates a horse boarding facility.

name: Naffziger House
mission_description: Boyhood Home of Howard Christian Naffziger. 1884  M.D., F.A.C.S. 1961. World-renowned neurosurgeon. Professor of surgery, Chief of Surgery and Neurosurgery at University of California Medical School; and Regent of the University of California. House built in 1859 by J. H. Helms. Note: James Harvey Helm (not "Helms") was a City Trustee and operated the Empire Livery Stable on Broad Street.

name: Bridgeport Covered Bridge
address: Pleasant Valley Rd at South Fork of Yuba River
mission_description: This covered bridge across the South Fork of the Yuba River at Bridgeport, Nevada County. Built in 1862 by David Isaac John Wood with lumber from his mill in Sierra County, this bridge was part of the Virginia Turnpike Company Toll Road which served the Northern Mines and the busy Nevada Comstock Lode. Utilizing a combination truss and arch construction, it is one of the oldest housed spans in the West and the longest single span, wooden covered bridge in the United States.The plaque is dedicated to those pioneer Americans who came to California in search of a new life and passed this way to establish their homes in the Northern Mine country. Note: The second plaque is full of errors. Bridgeport originally was known as "Nye's Landing" because Urias and Manuel Nye built a trading post here in 1849, but "Nye's Crossing" was on the Middle Fork of the Yuba River, near the mouth of Oregon Creek. Furthermore, the builder's name was David Ingerfield John Wood.

name: First Long Distance Telephone
address: In front of private home at 20342 Pleasant Valley Rd, four m. west of Hwy 49
mission_description: Built in 1877, the Ridge Telephone Co., connected French Corral with French Lake 58 miles away. It was operated by the Milton Mining Co., from this building which was built about 1853. This plaque donated by Sadie Winn Brainard. Note: This plaque was originally placed on the brick building in which the telephone office was located. After the building was razed in 1955 it was placed on a concrete monument on the shoulder of the present Pleasant Valley Road in front of a neighboring residence. The 1877 date is an error. The line began operation in 1878. The claim of being the "world's first" is still being debated. However, its challengers did not have the track record of the Ridge Telephone Company, which operated successfully into the 20th century over a much longer distance.

name: Rough and Ready Town Site
address: Rough and Ready Hwy, corner Chapel Rd, Rough and Ready
mission_description: Rough and Ready. Established In 1849, and named after the Rough and Ready Company of miners from Wisconsin, in honor of General Zachary Taylor, this was one of the principal towns of Nevada County. Here in 1850, articles of secession were drawn up establishing the 'Republic of Rough and Ready.' As a result of disastrous fires, only a few structures remain today of those built in the 1850s.

name: Fippin's Blacksmith Shop
address: 14482 Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
mission_description: Republic of Rough and Ready April 1850 - July 1850. This community of 3000 people seceded from the Union to declare a free and independent state. Colonel E. F. Brundage was elected president. Congressional action on California statehood was pending at the time. Built in the mid 1850s by John Fippin and John Single. Fippin married Single's daughter Julia in 1867, and they raised 10 children. Local legend has it that one of Lotta Crabtree's earliest performances was atop the anvil here. The building today is a combination of the original blacksmith shop and Single's carpenter shop. W. H. (Bill) Fippin and Frank A. Fippin followed their father as smiths and ran the business until well into the 20th century. Members of the Fippin and Single families have served Rough and Ready for generations as County officials, School Trustees and Postmasters.

name: Rough and Ready Toll House
address: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
mission_description: This house and the adjacent property contain five plaques. First plaque: Built in 1859 by Benoni Thompson to collect tolls for using the Gephardt Union Turnpike running 6 miles from Penn Valley to Grass Valley. The last remaining original toll house in the West. It served as a Wells Fargo Express office and stage stop, and was the secret rendezvous place of Joaquin Murietta and Lola Montez. [Note: The reference to Joaquin Murietta and Lola Montez must be taken with a grain of salt and credited to the droll humor of E Clampus Vitus. There is no evidence of such a friendship, although anything was possible in the Old West.]

name: Rough and Ready Schoolhouse Site
address: 10079 Blue Creek Rd, south side of Old Rough and Ready Hwy, opposite Cemetery entrance
mission_description: Note: Present owner requests privacy. Landmark: The original one-room Rough and Ready school was built in 1868. It served the community for many generations before being destroyed in the Trauner Fire of 1994. The house Kevin and Gaylene Collins built here in 1995 has an exterior like that of the schoolhouse.

name: Toll Road Stake
address: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
mission_description: Second Plaque: Toll Road Stake. Across the street from this location is a tree stump in which the original stake exists that was used to close off the passage to travelers from Grass Valley to Penn Valley. Drivers who frequented this road had to stop at this location and pay the toll. Once appropriate compensation was provided, the gate would be opened to allow passage.

name: China Wall
address: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
mission_description: Third plaque: The China Wall. In the 1850s, Chinese laborers, who were an essential part of the community, built the wall you see before you. Large natural stones were hand stacked for its construction. The wall extends 5 miles in either direction, however much of it has disintegrated over the years. This lot, along with the lot across the Gephardt's Union Turnpike, and the adjoining lots, are referred to in the Nevada County tax records as the ïChina LotsÍ as evidence of their history.

name: Rowe Saw Mill
address: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
mission_description: Fourth plaque: Rowe Saw Mill. In the 1860s there were four saw mills in this area. This display, in honor of his founding fathers, is from the Tom Rowe Saw Mill, and displays how the mill works. The foreman stood in the cage and called out the beam size (8x8, 12x12, etc.) then the cutter set the blade which was on a track, and rode the blade down the track until the beam cut was complete. The beam then went to the mines to build the shafts.

name: Indian Grinding Rock
address: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
mission_description: Fifth plaque: Indian Grinding Rock. Indian women used grinding rocks such as these, along with a linear rock called a ïpestleÍ to grind grass seeds, acorns and other foods during the meal preparation process, which included gathering, storing, leaching and cooking. It is believed each hole here served as many as three people, and the six holes here represent the possibility that this encampment contain 18 people total. Acorns, grass seeds and roots provided a diet rich in starch and fat. These Indians were nicknamed the ïDigger IndiansÍ by the local immigrants.

name: North Star Mine Powerhouse and Nevada County Traction Company
address: Allison Ranch Rd at McCourtney Rd, Grass Valley
mission_description: The North Star Powerhouse, built by A. D. Foote in 1895, was the first complete water powered compressed air transmission plant of its kind. Compressed air, generated by Pelton water wheels, furnished power for the entire mine operation. The 30-foot Pelton wheel was the largest in the world, and was in continuous use for over 30 years.Second plaque dedicated 1991 by American Society of Mechanical Engineers: International Mechanical Engineering Heritage Collection Pelton Water Wheel Collection North Star Power House Museum. The Pelton Wheel uses the momentum of a water jet impinging on buckets attached to the periphery of a wheel to produce power. It is a development of the primitive, so-called 'Hurdy Gurdy' wheel used in the California goldfields in the nineteenth century. Various inventors have contributed this type of water turbine, including Lester A. Pelton (1831-1908), who in 1880 patented the characteristic split bucket form. Subsequent important contributions to Pelton-Wheel technology were made by W. A. Doble. This collection illustrates the origin and development of the Pelton Waterwheel. American Society of Mechanical Engineers-1991.Third plaque dedicated 1997 by Historical Society near smaller wheel: Pelton Type Water Wheel. Produced 71000 hp at 327 rpm, diameter 10 ft. Weight 26,000 lbs. Built by Allis Chalmers of single cast nickel steel. Gift of Oroville-Wyandotte Irrigation Dist.  Note: The building presently houses the Historical Society's Mining Museum.

name: Idaho Maryland Core Sample
address: Nevada County Fairgrounds, McCourtney Rd, Grass Valley
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 1961 by Historical Society: Core - Weight 11 Tons. Portion taken from Idaho Shaft No. 2 bored to a vertical depth of 1,125 feet, diameter of shaft five feet, the core boring barrel was invention of J. B. Newsom, mining engineer. Was used as an experiment by the Idaho Maryland Mine Corporation under general manager Errol MacBoyle. With the cooperation of the directors of the 17th District Agricultural Association, through their manager, Malcolm E. Hammill, this core was erected in July 1961. Note: The Newsom drilling machine bored a round shaft, using no explosives. It was cheaper because no timbering was needed. Similar cores are displayed at Calanan Park and Empire Mine Park.

name: North Star House
mission_description: This 1905 structure was built for Arthur D. Foote, manager of the North Star mine from 1895 to 1913, and his wife, Mary Hallock Foote, a noted 19th-century author and illustrator. The structure was designed by Julia Morgan, California’s first licensed female architect and designer of the Hearst properties at San Simeon, Asilomar in Pacific Grove, and numerous buildings on the U. C. Berkeley campus, and in total, over 700 buildings. The property is representative of the era that brought Nevada County to the forefront of gold production in California.

name: Old Auburn Road Bridge (Site)
address: Old Auburn Rd, southeast of modern bridge over Wolf Creek about 4 m. south of McCourtney Rd
mission_description: The Old Auburn Bridge was registered as a landmark in 1996 by Nevada County. The bridge consisted of a single span, pin-connected steel pony truss, 66-feet in length, 11-feet in width, with a timber deck carrying a single traffic lane. It was built in 1897 by Cotton Brothers and Co. of Oakland, California. In 2004, the old bridge was dismantled by the County as unsafe and replaced by a modern span. Recognizing the historical significance of the spot, the County erected a monument containing a bronze plaque: Historic Marker Perrin Crossing. This bridge replaces the original steel truss span constructed in 1897 and remained in continuous service until 2004. This crossing received its name from Joseph and Susan Perrin, who settled nearby in 1851. Close to this crossing the Perrin family operated a stagecoach stop known for its hospitality. This road was part of the original stagecoach route between Sacramento and Grass Valley. Note: Remains of the stagecoach stop can be seen about 100 ft. south of the monument

name: Wolf Post Office
mission_description: The Nevada County Historical Landmarks Commission is pleased to announce the installation and dedication of a plaque honoring the Wolf Post Office on Sunday, October 6, 2019. Ranchers and farmers began to settle the historic agricultural community of Wolf in the 1860s. William Sweet arrived in Wolf in 1869, immigrating from Cornwall, and purchased 200 acres before his wife and children joined him in 1871. On August 24, 1888, a post office was established for the growing population of Wolf. John Sweet, one of William’s sons, ran the post office from the living room of his ranch house and it soon became a community center and gathering place for approximately 75 residents of Wolf. It is believed that John Sweet was the longest serving U.S. Postmaster, continually running the Wolf Post Office for 52 years until his nephew W. B. Sweet took over on February 19, 1940. W. B. moved the Post Office from his uncle’s home to a small building close by and served the Wolf community until 1956 when the post office was decommissioned with only 2 residents utilizing the service.

name: Overland Emigrant Trail--Highway 49
address: Hwy 49 south of Grass Valley, 1.2 m. north of Combie Rd between Clivus Dr and Brewer Rd at South Wolf Creek bridge
mission_description: At this point, the old Overland Emigrant Trail approaches the present highway. More than 100-years ago it resounded to the creaking wheels of pioneer wagons and the cry of hardy but footsore travelers buoyed by the realization that their long trip to the goldfields was about over.

name: Root Cellar on Mexican War Land Grant
address: 16330 Gibboney Lane, Grass Valley. Take Hwy 49 to Alta Sierra intersection and follow Alta Sierra Dr to Gibboney Lane
mission_description: This old root cellar is located on property that originally was part of a Land Grant of 160 acres granted to Josiah Dodge by President Ulysses Grant in 1873 as Bounty Land for his service as a private with Captain Steen's Co., 1st U.S. Dragoons, War with Mexico. In 1878 this property became part of the John Bree Ranch. The root cellar, built by Bree in the 1880s, was used to store his produce. Mr. Bree was among the first in the county to plant a Bartlett Pear orchard for commercial purposes.

name: Empire Mine
address: Empire Mine State Historic Park, 338 E. Empire St, Grass Valley
mission_description: This plaque marks the site of the Empire Mine, noted for its continuous operation 1850-1957 producing over $120,000,000 in gold.

name: Chicago Park Historic Agricultural Community
address: Along Hwy 174 between the Bear River and Brunswick Rd
mission_description: The Chicago Park Historic Agricultural Community occupies roughly the area on either side of Highway 174 between the Bear River and Brunswick Road. It is centered on the villages of Chicago Park and Peardale. Prior to the 1840s, this area was populated by the Nisenan. In August 1849, what is reported to have been Nevada County's second store was erected on land overlooking the junction of the Bear River and Greenhorn Creek. In the 1850s, local residents led by Simmon Storms succeeded in having the Nisenan removed to a reservation near Tehama. During that period, Benjamin Taylor settled on a ranch in the area which he named Buena Vista, after the Mexican War battle in which he had participated, and engaged in farming and horse breeding. Others who settled in the area found it very suitable for growing fruit, especially pears.In 1872, the Coleman Brothers purchased the Buena Vista and Storms ranches, and other properties in the area, as they were developing the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. Completed in 1876, the Railroad spurred the agricultural development of the area. In 1887, a group of Colfax and Chicago, Illinois developers acquired several thousand acres of land and drew up plans for the Chicago Park Colony. The Colony was to consist of 20 and 40 acre tracts as well as town lots laid out around a public square with streets named for prominent streets in Chicago. Much of the planned development never materialized, but reportedly almost 7000 acres were sold, principally to residents of Chicago. Many of the tracts were planted with orchards, and the area was referred to as the Bartlett Pear Belt. The railroad station at Storms Station was renamed Chicago Park Station, There were also stations at Buena Vista and Peardale. Fruit was king in the area for about 100-years. Orchards growing pears, plums, peaches and apples were everywhere. Because water was not abundant, dry farming techniques were mastered which improved fruit color. In 1915, local Bartlett pears were honored at the Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco. As the 20th century progressed, pear blight appeared, causing some growers to switch to other crops.

name: Rollins Dam and Reservoir
address: Larsen Rd about 1000 ft from Orchard Springs access road to Rollins Lake, Chicago Park
mission_description: Two plaques dedicated 1966 by Nevada Irrigation District:  "Nevada Irrigation District, Yuba-Bear River Development, Rollins Dam & Reservoir Completed 1965.” "To all those individuals and agencies whose foresight, labors and support made possible the construction of this project and the benefits the entire region derives from its features."

name: Old Pacific Fruit Packing Shed
address: Mount Olive and Lower Colfax Rds, Chicago Park
mission_description: A smaller shed, built here in 1926, collapsed during a snowstorm in 1929. Its successor was built in 1930 by the Civilian Conservation Corps. The Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad tracks, depot, and water tower were alongside this building, where peaches and pears from the surrounding orchards were packed and sent to Colfax by train. There the boxes were transferred to standard sized refrigerator freight cars to be shipped to the East.

name: Saint Paul Lutheran Church Site
address: St. Paul Pl. east of Hwy 174 at Chicago Park. St. Paul Cemetery is first left past the fire station
mission_description: On this site donated by Anna Pusheck the German Evangelical Lutheran St. Paul congregation was established in 1902 for worship and praise to God, continuing until 1984. Note: Anna Pusheck was the mother of Dr. Charles Pusheck, one of the Chicago Park Colony's developers. In 1895, he built a sanitorium in Chicago Park, which he later converted to a hotel. The St. Paul Lutheran church building was dedicated in December 1904. After the church was destroyed by fire on MotherÍs Day 1971, services were held in the parsonage until 1984. Most services and record keeping were in the German language until 1924. From then until 1942 both English and German were used to compile important data, and English services were held once a month. An English-language hymnal was used for the first time on September 28, 1924. After the outbreak of World War II the use of German was discontinued altogether.

name: You Bet Town Site
address: Red Dog Rd, between Lowell Hill and Chalk Bluff Rds, six m. east of You Bet Rd exit on Hwy 174
mission_description: This mining camp, established between 1858-1860, consisted of 40 or 50 buildings by 1864. A school house was built midway between You Bet and Red Dog. The town was destroyed by fire in April 1869, partially rebuilt, and burned again in September 1873 and August 1915. The courts halted most hydraulic mining in 1884, but gold mining continued until the 1940s. The You Bet Post Office was closed in 1903.

name: Red Dog Town Site
address: Red Dog Rd, 3 m. north of You Bet Rd intersection. 0.5 m. southeast of Greenhorn Creek
mission_description: Note: The site is a federally restricted area. Red Dog (1851-1871), with a population of 2,000 at its peak, was the third town of importance in Nevada County, surviving longer than most of the earliest gold towns. The Post Office closed in 1869.

name: Old Bear River Bridge
address: Hwy 174 at Bear River, between Colfax and Chicago Park
mission_description: Since 1852 bridges near this site have served as the gateway to western Nevada County. This 1924 span was the first concrete bridge at this site and features a Roman style single arch design, constructed in a continuous pour method. The Colfax Highway Association led a citizens group that saved the bridge from the wrecker’s ball in 1986, and placed this monument in 1992.

name: Veterans Memorial Flagstaffs, Grass Valley
address: Entrances to Greenwood and Catholic cemeteries, W. Main St, Grass Valley
mission_description: Plaques and flagstaffs dedicated 1954 by Post 130, American Legion Auxiliary: Lest We Forget. This memorial flagstaff dedicated in eternal memory of those war veterans resting within the portals of this cemetery who served in the wars of our nation and those who gave their lives defending AmericaÍs eternal freedoms.

name: Gilmore Flying Field
address: Lyman Gilmore School, corner Gilmore Way and W. Main St, Grass Valley
mission_description: Gilmore Flying Field. This windsock marks the site of one of the first flying fields in the United States. Here Lyman Gilmore, a contemporary of the Wright Brothers, pioneered in aviation by designing and building his own planes and gliders as early as 1898. Plaque on monument in front of school dedicated 1968 by Grand Lodge, Free and Accepted Masons: Lyman Gilmore, Jr. 1874-1951. Lyman Gilmore, Jr. established the first commercial airport on this site in 1907. To him and his memory the people of this community dedicate this school as the Lyman Gilmore School. Note: Gilmore did not use this field until the winter of 1911-12. As the Daily Transcript reported on January 29, 1912, "The principal place of business [of the Gilmore Airship Co.] was recently moved from Colfax to Grass Valley, and the meeting on Saturday evening was the first with the present board of directors." This pole was used originally at Gilmore Field, which Gilmore always claimed was the first commercial airport on the West Coast. The CETA mural on the north wall of the multipurpose building was painted in 1978.

name: Glasson House
mission_description: This Victorian/Greek Revival house was built in 1866 for Miles P. O'Connor, who came to California in 1849 and to Nevada County in 1852. He served as justice of the peace for Little York township in 1852-53 and for Grass Valley 1862-69. He served one term in the state assembly and two in the state senate. He earned a fortune from the famous Idaho gold mine and was instrumental in creation of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. After selling this house to John Polglase in 1873, he moved to San Jose and funded various institutions, including a sanitarium later known as O'Connor Hospital. John Polglase, a hard-rock miner from Cornwall, came to Grass Valley in 1864. In 1875 Polglase bought an interest in John Glasson's grocery and provisions store while continuing to work underground in the Idaho mine. In 1882 he sold the house to his partner, and Glasson and his heirs owned it from then until 1973. John Glasson, like Polglase, came here in 1864 from England, and like O'Connor he played a prominent role in Nevada County history. He bought the local gas company in 1885-86 and in 1888 merged it with the Grass Valley Electric Light and Motor Co. He built the countyÍs first hydroelectric plant at Deer Creek Falls and was a director and treasurer of the Narrow Gauge railroad. His daughter Bernice was a major benefactor to the Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital, and she lived in this house until her death in 1966.

name: Holbrooke Hotel
mission_description: Holbrooke Hotel Founded 1851. California’s oldest hotel in continuous operation. Among its century-old archives are names of such notables as Presidents Grant, Harrison, Cleveland; authors Mark Twain, Bret Harte; boxers Corbett, Fitzsimmons; actor Gilbert Barry, and highwayman Black Bart. Present structure built in 1862 following infamous fire.Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1978 by State of California, CHL 914: ñThe present bar of the hotel has been in continuous operation since 1852, when it was known as the Golden Gate Saloon. The wooden building had a rear extension called The Exchange Hotel and offered food and lodging by January 1853. The saloon was destroyed in the fire of 1855 and rebuilt out of fieldstone with a brick front. The Holbrooke, built in 1862, had the adjacent Golden Gate Saloon incorporated in the hotel building.Third plaque dedicated by Grass Valley Downtown Association: Presidential Square. These Presidents of the United States have visited this site: Ulysses S. Grant, James A. Garfield, Benjamin Harrison, Grover Cleveland, Herbert Hoover.  Note: No evidence exists that some of these notables stayed at the Holbrooke or visited Grass Valley.  Local lore has it that Gilbert Barry is a Clamper fabrication.

name: Williams Stationery Store
mission_description: This building is known as 'The Brick Store of Silvester and Salaman‰' it was built in 1854 and completed in 1855 by Henry Silvester and Abraham Salaman. It is both the first and oldest original brick (and stone) building in Grass Valley and the second oldest brick building in Nevada County. There have only been three owners of this building, Henry Sylvester, Paul Wesley Michell, and Elton and Helen Williams. Only five businesses have occupied the store in 145 years, H. Silvester Grocery, H. J. Fuchs Grocery, C. W. Jenkin Variety Store, Tresize Brothers Stationery Store, Williams Brothers, later changed to Williams Stationery Store.

name: Binkelmann Brewery
mission_description: Born in Wurtemberg, Germany on January 2, 1828, David Binkelmann came to Grass Valley in 1853 after only a year as a new immigrant in New York. He mined for a time on Wolf Creek, then worked in a bakery. He became a renter of the business, but after two years sold the bakery operation to Herrman Maurer and bought a half-interest in a brewery with John Frank, operating in the rear of the Western Hotel which burned in 1856. The brick brewery was constructed in 1861, replacing a smaller 1856 frame building on North Auburn Street. Frank Richard bought out the partner in 1861 and was in turn bought out by Binkelmann shortly later. He ran the brewery until his death on May 23, 1894, leaving his wife Sophie to carry on until her death in 1915, when the brewery was bequeathed to her son, David J. Binkelmann. Note: The Brewery building, which has a beautiful vaulted brick cellar, has been incorporated into the hotel across the street.

name: Washington Brewery
mission_description: Founded 1858 by John Frank, the brewery operated until prohibition. The ownership remains in the Frank family to the present time. Note: The Frank family sold the building in 1973. It no longer functions as a brewery.

name: Red Ledge Stamp Mill
address: Corner of Main and Auburn Sts, Grass Valley
mission_description: Stamp Mill. This three stamp mill was donated to the City of Grass Valley by Mrs. Stella Tracy, owner of the famous Red Ledge Mine near Washington, Nevada County, where this mill crushed tons of gold bearing ore for many years. It is erected here in memory of the 'Cousin Jack' miners who came from Cornwall, England with their knowledge of hardrock mining used to bring gold bearing quartz to the surface from the deep mines of the area.

name: Dr. W. C. Jones Home Site
address: 129 S Auburn St, now Grass Valley Police Dept
mission_description: Dr. W. C. Jones came to Grass Valley in 1874 after serving as physician and surgeon for the Central Pacific Railroad Co. during construction of the railroad between Colfax and Reno. He had three sons, Will, John, and Carl, who along with their father served the community as doctors until the last son died in 1944. In 1904 Dr. John Jones opened the first private hospital in Nevada County-the W. C. Jones Memorial Hospital, Grass Valley. A fourth son, George, became Superior Court Judge of Nevada County, serving from 1908 until 1925 and again from 1938 until he retired in 1947. Note: The city removed the historic house to make room for the police department.

name: Chinatown Grass Valley (Site)
address: Corner of Tinloy and Bank Sts, Grass Valley
mission_description: Chinatown, Grass Valley 1850-1938. Of the many gold rush Immigrants the Chinese were noted for their honest, sober and industrious characteristics. Each mining camp had its Chinatown and Grass Valley was second only to San FranciscoÍs. Former residents Duck Egg, Georgie Bow, Ah Louie, and the pioneer Yuen, Gon and Tinloy families are an integral part of Nevada County’s history. Note: Georgie Bow went to China, where he was in the diplomatic service. Chinatown was torn down in 1939 to make way for a truck terminal. Now the site is occupied by a hotel and parking lot.

name: Grass Valley Hardware
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 1969 by Native Daughters and Native Sons of the Golden West: Through the years of prospecting hydraulic and hardrock mining this hardware business, one of CaliforniaÍs oldest, has served the community. In continuous operation at this site since 1854.

name: Edward Coleman House
address: 318 Neal St, corner School St, Grass Valley
mission_description: The Edward Coleman House. Edward Coleman built this house in 1866. While residing here, Coleman was President/Superintendent of the Idaho Mine, Director of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad, and had interests in the Mohawk Lumber Company. Coleman sold this house in 1893.

name: Caroline Mead Hanson House
address: 319 Neal St, corner of S. Church St, Grass Valley
mission_description: Homesite of Caroline Mead Hanson. Whose idea sparked the annual Donation Day sponsored by Grass Valley Ladies Relief Society since 1883. Note: Home of the originator of Grass Valley's Donation Day, that began In 1883. Mrs. Hansen, an invalid, sat in the bay window of her home and watched the children troop to school. Hearing of the Ladies Relief SocietyÍs shortage of funds she suggested a plan to help the needy share the Feast of Christmas. Each child would bring a stick of wood and a potato to school on the same day named by the school superintendent. The potatoes would be put in a sack provided by the janitor; the wood would be piled in the school yard. On the following day these donations would be removed by the Relief Society and dispensed as needed. Mrs. Hansen conveyed her plan in a letter to the Grass Valley Daily Union that was published November 20, 1883. Since that date thousands of Grass Valley school children and citizens have marched in the Donation Day parade.

name: Grass Valley's Famed Maple
address: Neal St, in private yard at corner of School St, Grass Valley
mission_description: This beautiful, Brandywine Maple, subject for artists and photographers, was brought from the fields of Gettysburg, and planted in 1876 by the widow of the poet and editor of the Grass Valley National newspaper, John Rollin Ridge. Surviving the fire which leveled the home, it now adorns the lovely Victorian home built by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Clinch in 1900. Roy Clinch Tremoureux, grandson, notes proudly that many trees which beautify our town have come from this famed maple. Note: Time has ravaged the maple.

name: Bell Hill School Bell
address: Bell Hill School, 342 S. School St, Grass Valley
mission_description: The Bell Hill School Bell 1877. This school bell is lovingly dedicated to the children and teachers of the Grass Valley School District who daily answered its melodious tone. The bell was cast at the Buckeye Bell Foundry in Cincinnati by Vanduzen and Tift, and the rotary yoke was patented in 1868. The bell was placed in this beautiful monument by Harold J. Perry, a member of the Grass Valley Host Lions Club. Dedicated March 30,1985 as a part of the 100th Anniversary Celebration of Quartz Parlor No. 58.

name: Mt. Saint Mary's Convent and Academy
mission_description: Mt. St. Mary's School. To this spot Father Thomas J. Dalton brought the Sisters of Mercy in 1863. The Sisters of Mercy have taught here since that date. Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1972  Built by the Reverend Thomas J. Dalton and dedicated May 2, 1865 by Bishop Eugene O'Connell as Sacred Heart Convent and Holy Angels Orphanage. Under the Sisters of Mercy it served from 1866 to 1932 as the first orphanage of the Northern Mines. It functioned as an academy (1868-1965) and a convent (1866-1968).

name: St Patrick's Cemetery
address: Corner Chapel and Church Sts, Grass Valley
mission_description: St. Patrick’s Cemetery 1853. In memory of the pioneers buried here. A sign nearby contains this information: Site of the first Catholic Church in Grass Valley. Dedicated on October 25,1853. Rev. John Shanahan, 1st Pastor. Served as church 'till December 5, 1858. Served as the first Catholic School (1859-1879).

name: Empire House
mission_description: This site at the lower end of Boston Ravine on the old main road from Grass Valley to Auburn has been the location of a public house since 1851. Charles Behrisch was the owner from 1851 to 1885. Ownership changed hands many times through the years. Purchased by Dominic Pajnich on August 1,1933, and was burned in 1934. Replaced with a 14-room hotel, named Empire Inn. Upstairs closed off in 1964, but remains a popular food and beverage stop today. Boston Ravine, established in 1849, was the earliest mining community in the area which subsequently grew into Grass Valley.

name: Gold Quartz Discovery
address: Corner of Jenkins St and Hocking Ave, Grass Valley
mission_description: This tablet commemorates the discovery of gold-bearing quartz and the beginning of quartz mining in California. The discovery was made on Gold Hill by George McKnight October, 1850 The occurrence of gold-bearing quartz was undoubtedly noted here and elsewhere about the same time, or previously, but the above discovery created the great excitement that started the development of quartz mining into a great industry. The Gold Hill Mine from 1850 to 1857 is credited with a total production of $4,000,000.

name: Lola Montez House Replica
mission_description: Lola Montez (1819-1861) Countess of Landsfeld. In her home which occupied this site, Lola’s social salons 1853-1855 attracted men of vision whose investments and technology founded Nevada CountyÍs gold quartz mining industry. She brought culture and refinement to this rude mining camp. A mistress of international intrigue and a feminist before her time she is one of history’s most recognizable women and a founder of today’s cosmetic industry. Note: After earlier building was torn down this replica of original house was built. It now houses a small museum. LolaÍs house had been the office of Grass Valley Quartz Mining Co., the first consolidated effort at deep underground mining. Also site of first school in Grass Valley, a private school run by Rosa Farrington in 1851 before she moved to School Street.

name: Emmanuel Episcopal Church
mission_description: Historic Emmanuel Episcopal Church. Oldest Episcopal edifice in California. First services April 23, 1854 by Rt. Rev. William I. Kip, Bishop of Calif. This building opened for worship Aug. 1856. Note: The church was declared eligible for National Landmark status in 1982, but the vestry declined to have the church registered. The first services mentioned above were held in "a public hall" according to an account by Bishop Kip. On December 11, 1856, the Gold Hill Mining Company donated land to the parish that was bounded by Church, Walsh and Mill streets. The present church opened for worship in 1858. It is the oldest existing Episcopal Church in continuous use in California.

name: Crabtree House
mission_description: Lotta Crabtree was born in New York in 1847. In 1852 the gold fever brought Mr. Crabtree to California, and a year later his wife and Lotta followed. Several months after arriving in San Francisco Mrs. Crabtree and Lotta went to Grass Valley and started a boarding house for miners with Mr. Crabtree. It was here that Lotta met Lola Montez, who taught her to sing and dance. Lotta made her first public appearance in Plumas County, which led to a successful career on stage, both here and abroad.

name: Grass Valley Public Library (Josiah Royce Library)
mission_description: There are four plaques. First plaque and fir tree dedicated 1931 by Native Daughters and Native Sons of the Golden West: 1854 - Himalayan Fir - 1916. Planted In Memory of Dr. Josiah Royce one of AmericaÍs greatest scholars whose birthplace is the site of this Library. Second plaque dedicated 1933 by the Harvard Club of San Francisco: 1855 - Josiah Royce - 1916. Born in Grass Valley Alumnus of the University of California. Renowned Harvard teacher and eminent American philosopher. Third plaque and maple tree dedicated behind library ca. 1955 by the Harvard Club of San Francisco: Royce Centennial, to the memory of Josiah Royce Born here on November 20,1855. This tree was planted by the Harvard Club of San Francisco Veritas. Fourth plaque dedicated 1992 by the Friends of the Nevada County Libraries: Gift of Carnegie Corporation of New York. Dedicated August 4,1916. Note: The fir tree is now gone. In 2003 the County Board of Supervisors named the library for the renowned philosopher, who had died in 1916, the year in which the Carnegie Library opened its doors.

name: Dow Alexander Park
address: Corner Bennett and Bank Sts, Grass Valley
mission_description: Formerly known as the City Square, this park was established by the Grass Valley Women's Improvement Club in 1911, as a place of rest for patrons of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. It was dedicated to the pioneers and veterans of the Spanish American War. Second plaque: Last on duty at Fort Point on San Francisco Bay. Grass Valley Women’s Improvement Club arranged with the US War Department for donation to be placed in City Square, now Dow Alexander Park. Transferred from Benicia Arsenal to here in 1911. Only known example of its type to exist. Weight: 9100 pounds.

name: Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad (I)
address: Entrance at Bennett and Bank Sts, Grass Valley. Plaque at Bennett and Kidder Sts.
mission_description: Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad ran from here 5 miles N to Nevada City and 17 miles S to Colfax. Built 1874-76 by John F. Kidder whose home is NE corner. Depot and shops were 50 yards N., rails removed 1942. Sarah, widow of builder, was first woman R.R. president.

name: Reliance Hose Company No. 3
address: Race St near S. Auburn St, Grass Valley
mission_description: This Building, Housing Reliance Hose Company No. 3 since 1891, is hereby marked for preservation, thus honoring The Volunteer Fire Department of Grass Valley March 26, 1988 100th Anniversary of Manzanita Parlor #29, Native Daughters of the Golden West. Note: Marion Leech Conway's memoirs indicate the building was dedicated in December 1911, after housing the company for twenty years. "The doors of Reliance No. 3 have had the latch string out in welcome greeting to all when the word went out the Reliance would entertain its friends."

name: World War I Memorial, Grass Valley
address: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 1921: Honor Roll. Heroes from the Grass Valley District who gave their lives for their country 1917-1918: Anthony J. Bevilacqua, Robert H. Beyer, Lawrence A. Brasher, Melvyn Frandy, Isaac Leslie Fleming, Hedley Hill, Lenville Dooley Jatunn, William Hague, William A. Kneebone, Albert Pinkham, William Hawley Moran, James Rodgers, Clarence Crase Thomas, J. M. Spencer, Elton Thomas Whiting, John Edward White. Recently, a small plaque at the base of the main plaque added U.S. Army Nurse Elina W. Hill to the Honor Roll. Note: The above inscription is on a very large monument. Surrounding it is a grove of 16 trees, each with a marker in front inscribed with the name of one of these men and the American Legion logotype.

name: World War II & Korean War Memorial
address: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
mission_description: Plaque dedicated by Grass Valley Elks No. 538 and Frank Gallino Post No. 130 American Legion: World War II 1941-1946 Korean 1950-1955. To the men and women who made the supreme sacrifice for our country and her noble purpose, in memory of those who died that liberty might live. Note: Plaque is on a concrete monument that includes a flagpole and benches.

name: Vietnam War Memorials, Grass Valley
address: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
mission_description: Plaques dedicated 1966 and 1974 by Hague-Thomas-Hegarty (now Frank Gallino) Post No. 130, American Legion: 1966 plaque: Gary Ames Miller Memorial. This memorial is dedicated to all American servicemen and women of the Vietnam War in the name of Gary Ames Miller, United States Marine Corps, the first local serviceman to give the full measure for God and country in this conflict.
