name: Hard Rock Gold Mining
address: Memorial Park, Grass Valley, near creek by Race St culvert
mission_description: Hard Rock Gold Mining 1850-1957. Within a one-mile radius of this spot more than 500 million dollars worth of gold was produced by deep mines, including the Empire, North Star and the Idaho-Maryland. During that time this was the worldÍs most concentrated, efficient and innovative gold mining region.

name: Loutzenheiser Pharmacy Building/Foothill Flowers
mission_description: Operated by pioneer druggist William Loutzenheiser (1824_1905) and son, John G. (1861-1929). The pharmacy begin here in a wooden building in 1851. The structure gave way to the present brick edifice in the fall of 1855. William was a member of the 1861 city Board of Trustees, one of the original locators of the Idaho Quartz claim, and was active in several other mining ventures. On July 4, 1887 the pharmacy was the site of a bloody duel between two Grass Valley merchants, Henry Sylvester and John Davis, in which the latter was killed. In 1928 the business changed hands after 77 years of continuous operation by the Loutzenheiser family. Between 1928 and 1966 the building had many tenants. In the fall of 1966 Marie Johnson, known as the Flower Lady, founded Foothill Flowers. The interior of the building was destroyed by fire in May 1984 and was subsequently remodeled.

name: Shaar Zedek Grass Valley Jewish Cemetery
address: Location: Second Street off Eureka Street, Grass Valley
mission_description: Shaar Zedek, or the Gate of Righteousness, was established in 1856. The first burial was in 1857 and the last in 1891. Thirty headstones are visible. The cemetery was restored around 50 years ago by the Commission for the Preservation of Pioneer Jewish Cemeteries and Landmarks. It is locked and fenced to protect against vandalism.

name: The Old Post Office
mission_description: This building Is known as the Old Post Office. It was built in 1914 by the United States Government as the Grass Valley Post Office. From 1914 until 1984 the Post Office functioned for mail, package and gold shipments from the many mines in the area. After the Post Office moved to East Main Street the building operated as an Insurance Agency in the 1980’s and as professional offices since October 1989. Note: Plaque was dedicated in memory of Nevada County pioneer United States Senators Aaron Augustus Sargent (1873-1879) and William Morris Stewart (1865-1875 and 1887-1905).

name: Grass Valley Masonic Lodge
mission_description: Masonry in Grass Valley. Madison Lodge #23 was established under dispensation from the Grand Lodge of California on May 4th 1852. Its permanent charter was issued on May 5th 1853. Madison Lodge held its first two meetings at the old Columbus School on the present site of Hennessy School. The Lodge moved to a building on the south side of Main St.  where it now meets Auburn St.  This wooden building was destroyed along with most of Grass Valley in the great fire of September 12 and 13, 1855. A few days later, the Masons met with the Odd Fellows to select a site for a new brick building to house both organizations at 110 Mill St. This building was Madison's home for nearly 73 years, until fire destroyed the Masonic portion of the building in December 1928. For the next nine years the Lodge met in the auditorium of the old Strand Theater at 161 Mill St.  During this time, planning was being completed for our present building, which saw its first meeting on January 29, 1938. For 150-years, in both good times and bad, through 7 wars and a great depression, the Masonic spirit of Brotherly Love, Relief and Truth has continued on through our brethren of honorable men of all backgrounds, professions and faith. This plaque was set on May 9, 2002 in rededication ceremonies conducted by C. Ray Whitaker, Grand Master of Masons in California and Elmer B. Curtis, Master of Madison Lodge.

name: Grass Valley Historical District
mission_description: Dedicated in 1969 by the Grass Valley City Planning Commission. Description: A colorful, old gold-mining town established in 1849 at Boston Ravine and later named Grass Valley by a company of emigrants. The atmosphere of early mining days still clings to the town. Significant sites include the Empire Mine State Historic Park, the North Star House and the homes of Lola Montez and Lotta Crabtree.

name: The Auditorium Building
mission_description: The Auditorium Building. On July 30, 1896, a fire started here at the site of Argall’s Opera House, owned by Charles E. Clinch, burning the entire block on East Mill Street from Neal to Bank. In 1900, an incorporation composed of the Native Sons of the Golden West, Ancient Order of the Foresters, Knights of Pythias, Red Men, and the Miner’s Union was formed to build a fine theater of three stories. The first floor held a magnificent theater with a capacity of 600 on the floor and 250 in the gallery and office space for the Grass Valley City Hall. The second story was devoted to lodge rooms and the third story was a banquet hall. The basement housed both the kitchen and the armory for Company 1 of the National Guard. On February 2, 1901, the Auditorium Theater opened to a week-long celebration and operated until November 12, 1922. Two days later, it reopened as the Strand Movie Theater, operating until April 22, 1942. The building was then home of the F. S. Rasco & Co. store and since 1972 has been home to Hedman/Ashley furniture store.

name: Woman's Christian Temperance Union
address: North side of Neal St between Mill and S. Church Sts, Grass Valley
mission_description: The first Woman's Christian Temperance Union in California organized in Grass Valley March 25, 1874. Rededicated and second plaque placed 2014: Originally placed near the corner of Neal and South Church Streets near the site of the old Congregational Church and the Women's Improvement Club building. Note: In 1972, the Congregational Church building was demolished to make way for a bank building. The first plaque was removed and stored in the nearby Methodist Church. In 2014, it was rededicated by the Manzanita Parlor of the Native Daughters at its present location on a monument constructed from petrified wood.

name: Memorial Park GV
address: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
mission_description: Memorial Park was built in 1921 in memory of local armed forces members who died in World War I. The land and swimming pool were donated by the Empire Mine Co.; the club house was donated by the Idaho Maryland Mine Co.; and people of the area subscribed $8,000.  It now contains five plaques honoring those who served our country in the armed forces.

name: Marines Memorial
address: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 2003 by Marine Corps League Gold Country Detachment 885: "These memorials honor those who served in the Armed Forces of the United States of America. For those who returned, thank you God. For those who died, glory forever God. For those still missing, please God."

name: Pioneers Memorial
address: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
mission_description: Plaque  dedicated 1929 by Native Daughters  of the Golden West: In memory of our pioneer mothers & fathers dedicated June 12, 1929 by Manzanita Parlor No  29 N.D.G.W.

name: Nevada County Narrow Gauge (III)
address: Railroad Ave at back entrance to Northern Queen Inn, Nevada City
mission_description: For 66 years, the Nevada City depot served as the northern terminus for the railroad affectionately known as the 'Never Come Never Go.' In 1874 a group of 7 men, led by lumber mill and gold mine owner John C. Coleman, organized the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. Engineer John Flint Kidder was hired on January 14, 1875 to build a 23-mile narrow gauge railroad from the Central Pacific Railroad connection in Colfax to Grass Valley and Nevada City. On a snowy May 20, 1876, John Coleman drove the last spike in Nevada City to dedicate the completion of the railroad. John Kidder controlled the railroad from January 1884, until his death on April 10, 1901; the following day, his widow Sara was elected president of the railroad. Sara Kidder successfully managed the company until its sale on April 24, 1913 to the Oakland, Antioch and Eastern, a predecessor to the Western Pacific. On May 13, 1926, the N.C.N.G.R.R. was purchased by a group of local investors and it operated until December 1942. The scrapping of the railroad was completed by May 5,1943. Two other plaques at this location were dedicated on June 11,1994, but cannot presently be located.Text of second plaque: In fond appreciation of the known surviving employees of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad Co. 1876-1942. Bob Paine, Tony Dellea, Sadie Angelini, Eugene Katzer, Homer Bevared, George Jefferson, Edward Smith, Bill Tremewan.Text of third plaque: In grateful appreciation to the Northern Queen Inn and the Ramey family for their dedicated efforts in the restoration and preservation of Nevada County’s railroad history.

name: Glenbrook Basin
address: Sutton Way, south of Brunswick Rd, next to bus shelter in Glenbrook Plaza parking lot
mission_description: Early In the 1850's Glenbrook Basin first became known as the site of county fairs, horse racing and other special events. When Olympia Park, located at the south end of the basin, opened in 1901, Glenbrook Basin became the recreational center of Nevada County and much of Northern California, and remained so for over fifty years. People would come to the basin by horse and buggy or later the automobile, but those wishing for a little more excitement would often use the Nevada County Traction Company’s trolley, or the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. The large grandstands of the three-quarter-mile racetrack stood near the junction of present Brunswick Road and Sutton Way. Trotting, pacing, and running horse races were held at the track, and motor car races began in 1913. The racetrack was one of the first electrically lighted racetracks in the state. A dam was constructed just northeast of the existing electrical substation to form Lake Olympia. The lake soon became one of the BasinÍs main attractions. Located in the center of Lake Olympia was an island with a pavilion which had a coil-spring-mounted dance floor that swayed with the rhythm of the dancers' feet. There was swimming, boating and fishing in Lake Olympia, and during some winters there was ice skating. There were boats and bathing suits for rent, and the park contained a bathhouse, a roller skating rink, and a bar. Many a romance blossomed on the lake during an evening boat ride under the stars. Families rented cabins and picnicked in the shade of the large pine trees along the shores of Lake Olympia. Olympia Park was the site of high school commencements, football and baseball games, and special events such as fat ladies' races and freckled-face children contests. The annual miners' picnics were held at the park with mucking and drilling contests, tug-of-wars and Cornish wrestling, as refreshments of various kinds flowed freely. Olympia Park fell into disrepair in the 1950s and ceased operation in 1958. Glenbrook Basin, once the recreational center for Nevada County, has developed into one of the countyÍs main centers of commerce in supplying various types of shopping, restaurants, services and recreation for the residents and visitors of Nevada County.

name: The Union Newspaper
address: 11464 Sutton Way, Grass Valley, in the Glenbrook Basin
mission_description: Of the many historic newspapers started in the Northern Mines of the great Mother Lode during the famous gold rush era, only The Union of Grass Valley and Nevada City emerged a successful daily published for 100 years. Born in critical times: Civil War and presidential election. The Union has ever strived for unity and has evolved an independent voice supporting man and measure over partisanship. The Union is only the seventh daily newspaper in California to celebrate its Centennial under the original name. Centennial Date, October 28, 1964. Plaque dedicated when The Union newspaper was located on Mill Street, Grass Valley and moved with the newspaper to Sutton Way in December 1978.

name: Idaho-Maryland Mine Site
address: Hillside adjacent to Centennial Dr and Whispering Pines Lane, south of Idaho Maryland Rd, Grass Valley
mission_description: The Idaho quartz mine was discovered in 1863. It prospered under the Coleman brothers from 1867-93, then consolidated with the Maryland and other small mines. Eventually it became one of the 'Big Three' of the Northern Mines, the other two being the Empire and the North Star. Its final years under the management of Errol MacBoyle were very productive. He developed a revolutionary method of shaft sinking, using a huge core drill called the Newsom drilling machine. World War II and government order L208 brought about final closing. Note: Various parts of the mine still exist. The office building is off the east side of Centennial Drive, between Idaho Maryland Road and Whispering Pines Lane. A headframe is located near the Grass Valley Scrap, Iron & Metal yard. Learn more about the mine from Gold in Quartz: The Legendary Idaho Maryland Mine by Jack Clark, or from MacBoyle's Gold by Gage McKinney, both available from Comstock Bonanza Press.

name: Railroad and Transportation Museum
address: Five Kidder Court, Nevada City. Take Ridge Rd exit off Hwy 49
mission_description: The Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad (1876_1942) ran 22 miles from Nevada City through Grass Valley, its headquarters; to Colfax, Placer County, where it met the transcontinental line of the Central (later Southern) Pacific Railroad. Built by John F. Kidder, it was the main freight and passenger route serving the western county. Kidder ran the railroad until his death in 1901 and was followed by his widow Sarah, who became the first woman railroad president in United States. She served until 1913. This museum is dedicated to preserving the NCNGRR's place in history and to those who built, operated and maintained the little road. Second plaque dedicated 2011 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Railroad and Transportation Museum. The Nevada County Historical Society founded the Transportation Museum Division in 1983 to acquire, document, restore and preserve information and artifacts pertaining to Nevada County's railroad and transportation history. Best known is the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad that operated from 1876 until 1942. The museum opened for public enjoyment on March 17, 2003.

name: Nevada County Narrow Gauge RR (II)
address: Railroad Avenue at Sacramento St, Nevada City
mission_description: Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad was dedicated May 20, 1876 one hundred feet east of this spot. Built by John Flint Kidder between 1874-76 it ran 22 miles from Nevada City to Colfax via Grass Valley. Rails taken up in 1942. Sarah Kidder, widow of builder, worldÍs first woman railroad president 1901-13.

name: Nevada City Jewish Cemetery
address: End of King Hiram Lane, off Searls Ave, Nevada City
mission_description: The Nevada City Jewish Cemetery was established in 1854. The first burial was in 1856 and the last in 1890. Twenty nine headstones are visible, including that of Louis W. Dreyfuss, a cousin of Captain Alfred Dreyfus of France, the victim in the infamous Dreyfus Affair. The cemetery was restored around 50 years ago by the Commission for the Preservation of Pioneer Jewish Cemeteries and Landmarks. It is locked and fenced to protect against vandalism. Note: For more information see A Traveler's Guide to Pioneer Jewish Cemeteries of the California Gold Rush by Susan Morris.

name: Hydraulic Mining
address: Railroad Ave at back entrance to Northern Queen Inn, Nevada City
mission_description: The first hydraulic mining originated here at American Hill Diggins by Edward Matteson in 1853. Matteson originally used canvas hose. The canvas hose was replaced with crinoline hose in 1860. These miners' giants, also known as water cannons, monitors and dictators, washed hillsides away with high pressure water, uncovering gold bearing beds. This mining technique flourished profitably until 1884. Rivers were being filled with mud and debris causing flooding of the rich farm lands in the valley. At that time, a lawsuit brought by farmers against hydraulic mining was heard in Marysville, California where a decision known as The Sawyer Decision stopped all mining. Under a special use permit, granted by the Department of Fish and Game, these hydraulic monitors were last used at the Pacific Slab Mine near Foresthill, California in 1970, which was documented by the California Department of Parks and Recreation.

name: Pioneer Cemetery
address: East side of W. Broad St, near Hwy 49, Nevada City
mission_description: This cemetery was established in 1851 on a knoll back of the First Methodist Church. This gave the site its name. Many noted citizens rest here. Note: The first cemetery in Nevada County after arrival of the 49ers. Located in the churchyard of the first Methodist Church that once occupied this site, it has been in use since 1851. A wooden marker was placed in 1949. The plaque is on a stone monument in the front part of the cemetery. Many famous pioneers and early settlers are buried here, including Henry Meredith and William Alphonso Sutter, the son of General John Sutter. Aaron A. Sargent's cenotaph is here though his remains were cremated and scattered by air above the Quaker Hill Mine, which he used to own.

name: Englebright House
mission_description: Notable as one of the earliest recorded houses in Nevada City and for its history of prominent owners. The tradition that the legendary William Morris Stewart built the house in 1853 cannot be documented for no deeds remain earlier than 1858. However, the house appears as the residence of P. G. Womack in the first map of the city prepared in 1855 and published in 1856. Other owners included the famous mining engineer, Capt. Thos. Mein, whose son William Wallace Mein was born in the house in 1873. The family of the late U.S. Representative Harry Englebright purchased the house in 1897 and resided there until 1959. The interior shows the work of many occupants and the exterior reflects eclectic borrowings from many past styles.

name: Nathaniel P. Brown House
mission_description: Nathaniel P. Brown, founding owner of the Nevada Daily Transcript and early political figure in Nevada City, lived here from 1865 until 1909. He expanded the original cottage to its current size in the 1880s, allowing for frequent entertaining. The home was built in 1858 by Jesse S. Wall, an early settler and merchant. Nathaniel Brown came to Nevada City from Massachusetts in 1853 at the age of 18, following his friend Aaron Sargent. He was part owner of the weekly Nevada Journal from 1855 to 1859. In 1860, Brown founded the countyÍs first daily, the Morning Transcript, and from then until 1904 was prominent in newspaper circles and a constant champion of mine ownerÍs rights. The most famous resident of the house was opera diva Emma Nevada. While her father, Dr. W. W. Wixom, sought a new home for his family, Emma and her mother boarded here until 1864. Between the ages of 4 and 13 she resided at Austin, Nevada. Emma Wixom achieved great fame as a singer and took the stage name Nevada to honor the state in which she grew up and the county where she was born. She returned to Nevada City in 1902 and performed to a packed audience at the Nevada Theatre.

name: Indian Medicine Stone
address: 621 E. Broad St, opposite N. Pine St, Nevada City
mission_description: Pioneer Emigrant Trail. This boulder was known to the pioneers as the Indian Medicine Stone. On its top are hollows in which the Indians lay while taking sun baths to cure their ills. One branch of the Emigrant Trail leading from Truckee Pass to the gold mines of Nevada County and to the Valley of the Sacramento passed close beside this stone.

name: 545 Main Street
mission_description: Druggist and County Treasurer Edward F. Spence built this house on 3 lots in 1866 and lived here with his wife Marietta until her death in 1868. He founded Spenceville, organized banks in San Jose and Southern California, served as Mayor of Los Angeles, and was instrumental in establishing the Mt. Wilson Observatory. County Judge Addison C. Niles bought the house from Spence in 1870 and occupied it with his wife Elizabeth until his election to the California Supreme Court in 1871. The City of Niles, California, is named for him. Niles Searls bought the house from his brother-in-law, Addison Niles, in 1871. When he became a Supreme Court Commissioner in 1885 he and his wife Mary gave the house to son Fred and his bride, Helen Pond, as a wedding present. In 1887 Niles Searls became Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court, and served on the Supreme Court Commission from 1893 to 1899. Attorney Fred Searls (a native of Nevada City) and his wife Helen (a native of Downieville) lived here from 1885 until his death in 1929. The last member of the family to reside here was Fred Searls III, great-grandson of Niles Searls.

name: Baruh House
mission_description: The Baruh Home Built 1852. This site and home of two rooms was bought in 1866 by Mr. and Mrs. A. Baruh, grandparents of Mrs. Lucille Sherwood. Mrs. Clara Baruh Quigley, a charter member of Laurel Parlor No. 6, Native Daughters of the Golden West. Mr. Joseph Baruh, son, charter member of Hydraulic Parlor No. 56, Native Sons of the Golden West. Other family members: daughters Jenny Baruh Zellerbach, Rebecca Baruh Gabriel, sons Moses, Marcus and David. Mr. Aaron Baruh was a businessman operating a grocery store on Commercial Street, receiving gold dust for the commodities in the gold rush area. Later he operated a saloon and was very active in the early settlement of Nevada City. Note: Originally built by Jacob Coleman as a two-room cottage, it was expanded in 1866 by Aaron Baruh.

name: Saint Canice Catholic Church
address: Corner Washington and Coyote Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Historic St. Canice Catholic Church was built and first services held in 1864 under the guidance of Father John Griffin. Note: This also is site of St. Peter and St. Paul Catholic Church, built in 1857 and destroyed by fire in 1863.

name: Old Brick Gothic Church Building
address: Corner of Main and Church Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Historic Old Brick Gothic Building. Constructed as a Congregational Church in 1857. Restored by First Baptist Church. Notes: Also site of Nevada City’s pioneer nondenominational church, which burned in March 1851. It was replaced by a wooden Congregational Church, that burned in 1856. Cornerstone of this brick building was laid on July 4, 1858 (not 1857.) The roof and interior burned in 1863 and the church was rebuilt once more in 1864. The University of California was born at the church in 1853, when Henry Durant took part in a convention of Congregationalists and Presbyterians who resolved to establish a college in California. Durant soon opened the Contra Costa Academy in Oakland, that become the College of California then relocated to Berkeley as the University of California.

name: Nevada County Court House
address: 201 Church St, on left side of entrance, Nevada City
mission_description: Nevada County Courthouse History. Nevada County organized out of Yuba County May 11,1851. Wooden court-house and log jail built on Broad Street in 1851. The first courthouse on this site was erected in 1856. The building was damaged by fire in July of the same year and rebuilt. Destroyed by fire in 1863 and rebuilt in 1864. Remodeled and enlarged in 1900. Modernized and enlarged 1936-37, George C. Sellon, Architect, Lindgren and Swinerton, Inc., Contractors, Robert Steger, Building Superintendent.

name: First Brick Building in Nevada City
mission_description: Built in 1853. First brick building erected in this city. Dedicated to the memory of the pioneers of Nevada City. Note: This originally was the Dickerman carpenter shop. Bricks for this building were manufactured at Zeno P. Davis's brickyard on Lower Grass Valley Rd. in Nevada City (now called Searls Ave).

name: Searls Law Office
mission_description: This building completed December 18, 1872, was the law office for three generations of this family. Niles Searls, who arrived in 1851, practiced law here from 1872 to 1885. He had been elected district attorney in 1855, then district judge for Nevada, Sierra and Yuba counties, then became Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court in 1887. Fred Searls, his son, held the longest tenure in this building (1879-1929). He drafted the first incorporation papers of the hydroelectric industry of California. Carroll Searls, son of Fred, practiced here from 1915 to 1923; later became general counsel of the Newmont Mining Company in New York City; used this office until November 4,1970. Note: Niles Searls was elected district attorney in 1852, not 1855, but because he left California and went east to marry before his term of office began, William M. Stewart was appointed to fill the vacancy. Later, when Stewart resigned in 1854 to become the acting state attorney general, Searls was appointed to replace him as district attorney. From 1972 until 2014 the building housed the Historical SocietyÍs Searls Historical Library and Archives.

name: Doris Foley Library of Historical Research
mission_description: Nevada City Public Library. Library Association formed December 19, 1857. First library was in Kidd and Knox Building, 228 Broad Street. It was moved to Oustamah Lodge IOOF No. 16 June 3, 1874. Nevada City Trustees assumed responsibilities October 1, 1902 and was moved into the Corcoran Building next to the Nevada Theater. The Carnegie Endowment was given to the city in 1907. The present library was dedicated October 4, 1907. City groups raised funds for furnishings and beautified grounds 1911. Note: In 1996 the Nevada City Council, the Nevada County Board of Supervisors, and the Nevada County Historical Landmarks Commission voted to rename this library for Doris Foley, an outstanding historian and author who contributed greatly to scholarly research in this county. In addition to her writings, she helped found the Nevada County Historical Society and was the first librarian at Searls Historical Library. The Doris Foley Library of Historical Research was formally dedicated on May 17,1997.

name: Nevada City Firehouse No. 1
mission_description: Nevada Hose Co. No. 1 Occupied this firehouse from May 30, 1861 to 1938. Hand pulled hose carts, horse drawn engines and motorized pumpers all rolled out of this building to save life and property. Note: The building now houses the Historical Society Museum.

name: South Yuba Canal Office
mission_description: Headquarters for the largest network of water flumes and ditches In the state. The South Yuba Canal Water Company was the first incorporated to supply water for hydraulic mining. The original ditch was in use in May, 1850, and this company office was in use from 1857 to 1880. The holdings later became the vast P.G. & E. hydro-electric system.Second plaque dedicated 1987 by Native Sons of the Golden West: US Constitution 1787 Bicentennial 1987 Nevada City, a Bicentennial Community. The plaques are mounted on adjacent brick buildings. The one on the left originally was the Potter Building and the other began life as the City Drugstore, Both survived the great fire of 1856 and are two of the oldest in Nevada City. The South Yuba Canal Water Company did not occupy the building until 1861.

name: Five-Stamp Mill 1893
mission_description: Used to crush gold ore at the Fortuna Mine near Nevada City. Ore fed under iron 'stamps' from rear hopper. Steam, water or electric belt-driven power turned wheel which revolved cams. Donated to Nevada City by Bill Magers.

name: Pelton Water Wheel
mission_description: No. 4, 1928-1987. Produced 18,000 HP at 257 RPM and enough electrical power for 16,000 households. 12 ft. diameter, weight 15 tons. Built in San Francisco by Pelton Company. A Constitutional Bicentennial gift to Nevada City by Pacific Gas and Electric.

name: Original Ott Assay Office Site
mission_description: Site of the Original Ott Assay Office. J. J. Ott's assay in 1859 helped develop the great Comstock Lode and the State of Nevada. Note: Ott’s original Assay Office was built of wood. It burned in the fire of 1863 and Ott moved into the existing brick building next door.

name: Wells Fargo Building Site Nevada City
mission_description: Site of Old Wells Fargo Building 1853. Dedicated to the Pioneers of California by Hydraulic Parlor No. 56 N.S.G.W. July 5, 1926. Plaque erected by Wells Fargo Bank and Union Trust Co. S.F. Calif.

name: Calanan Park Monitor
mission_description: The first hydraulic mining originated on American Hill near Nevada City, California in 1853. This miner’s giant known as the monitor washed hillsides away under high pressure uncovering gold bearing gravel beds. This mining technique flourished profitably until 1884 when the Sawyer decision closed hydraulic mining. Rivers were being filled with mud and debris causing flooding of the rich farmlands below.

name: Calanan Park Drill Core
mission_description: Shaft Drill Core 1935-1936. Experimental vertical shaft, 5' in diameter to 1125' depth thru serpentine and gabbro at Idaho-Maryland Gold Mine, Grass Valley. Machinery invented by J. B. Newsom. Greatest drilled footage, 21' in three days. Core weight 11-tons. Donated to Nevada City by Kenneth E. Baker.

name: Nevada City Downtown Historic DIstrict
mission_description: Nevada City, the 'Queen City of the Northern Mines', became a town of 10,000 to 16,000 in the early 1850s following the discovery of gold on Deer Creek in 1849. Here is located the largest and best preserved historical downtown district in California Gold Country. As the county seat of Nevada County, Nevada City has maintained its position as the countyÍs center of government, professional services and cultural activities since its beginning in 1851 Entered National Register of Historic Places September 23,1985. Note: This includes only the downtown district, as contrasted to the Nevada City Historic District defined by the city in 1968.

name: Kidd and Knox Building
address: Northeast corner Pine and Broad Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Kidd & Knox Building 1856. Major commercial building since gold rush. early offices of judges, lawyers, statesmen including U.S. Senators A. A. Sargent, Wm. Morris Stewart; Calif. Supreme Court Chief Justices Niles Searls, Lorenzo Sawyer were here.

name: Nevada County Traction Company
address: Corner of Pine and Broad Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Nevada County Traction Company 1901-1924. Our 28-ton standard gauge street cars ran from this spot five miles to Boston Ravine south of Grass Valley. Car barns and power plant located at Glenbrook mid-way. Line was victim of motor cars and busses.

name: Nevada City Firehouse No. 2
mission_description: Firehouse #2 or Pennsylvania Engine Company #2 January 14,1861. Fire company formed June 13,1860 as Eureka Hose No. 2 with 34 volunteers. Name changed in August of that year to 'Pennsylvania Engine.' Construction money raised in 1859 by popular subscription and a grand ball staged by the townÍs women. This firehouse has been in continuous use since 1861. Note: The name change occurred after Eureka Hose #2 bought a used hose wagon from Pennsylvania Hose Co #12 in San Francisco. Because it was the easiest thing to do, they scratched off the 1 in #12  with a pen knife and changed their name to Pennsylvania Engine Company #2. The wagon is on display at the Wagon Shed (No. 113) in Pioneer Park.

name: Ten Stamp Mill
address: City parking lot on Commercial St, west of York St, Nevada City
mission_description: 'Six tall, upright rods of iron, as large as a manÍs ankle, and heavily shod with a mass of iron and steel at their lower ends . . .' So begins Mark Twain’s description of a Nevada stamp mill.' ... These rose and fell, one after the other, in a ponderous dance, in an iron box called a battery.' Each of the stamps weighed 600 pounds. 'One of us stood by the battery all day long, breaking up masses of silver-bearing rock with a sledge and shoveling it in.'  At the end of his brief stint shoveling ore into the Nevada stamp mill, Twain told his boss he thought the $10 a week was not quite enough. He asked for a new wage of $400,000 a month. He didn't get it and had to become a newspaperman.This ten stamp mill stands just two blocks from where it was manufactured at Miners Foundry in 1904. It operated at the Alpha mine in Sierra County from 1905 until 1931. Each stamp weighs 1,000 pounds and was used to crush gold-bearing rock. Gary Cope recovered the stamp mill in 1975. It was bought and erected on this site, Native Sons Park, by Hydraulic Parlor No. 56 of the Native Sons of the Golden West with the help of the Historic Preservation Foundation of the N.S.G.W. in 2005.

name: Aaron Augustus Sargent Homestead
mission_description: Homesteads of Nevada County’s Statesman, a 49er. Arrived here In 1850 as a journeyman printer. Editor and owner of the countyÍs first newspaper the Nevada Journal. Admitted to the bar 1854. District Attorney 1855-1857. First citizen elected to the House of Representatives 37th Congress 1861-1863; 41st and 42nd Congresses 1869-1873. First citizen elected to the United States Senate 1873-1879. Yeoman of the Republican Party. Author of the bill which created the first transcontinental railroad. Champion of the womanÍs suffrage movement, author of the Anthony Amendment giving women the right to vote; author of the Immigration Law, the first United States policy on immigration; author of the bill that revolutionized the mining industry, permitting mineral lands to be held in fee simple; author of the bill making the Pacific states and territories a U.S. Judicial Circuit; secured passage of the bill to establish a branch mint in the State of Nevada; secured appropriations for the construction of the mint and appraiser’s building in San Francisco. Envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary from the United States to the Court of Berlin, Germany, 1882-1884. Note: Ellen Clark Sargent, Aaron's wife, was one of the founders of the American suffrage movement. In 1869, she founded the Nevada County Women's Suffrage Organization. She was later president of the California Woman Suffrage association, and treasurer of the National Woman Suffrage Association. She was an associate of Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Sargent homes were always open to suffragists.

name: Nevada City Methodist Church
address: Corner Broad and Mill Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Historic Nevada City Methodist Church. Dedicated in 1864. Now one of the oldest existing churches.

name: Nevada Theatre
mission_description: Opened Sept. 11, 1865 with comic Dan Setchell and dancers Worrell Sisters. Built by Geo. S. Pierce. Mark Twain, Emma Nevada, Jack London, Gilbert Barry and Richard Jose performed here. Movies shown from 1908-1958 Acquired 1967 by Liberal Arts Commission for restoration. Second plaque dedicated 1974 by State of California in cooperation with the Nevada County Historical Landmarks and Liberal Arts Commissions: CaliforniaÍs oldest existing theatre building, the Nevada, opened September 9, 1865. Celebrities such as Mark Twain, Jack London and Emma Nevada have appeared on its stage. Closed in 1957, the theatre was later purchased through public donations and reopened May 17, 1968 to again serve the cultural needs of the community. Note: Jack London’s appearance in the Nevada Theatre is undocumented and Gilbert Barry's may be a Clamper fabrication.

name: Nevada City Hall
mission_description: First plaque dedicated 1937 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Dedicated June 19,1937 to the Pioneer Councilmen who erected the first City Hall  Felix Gillet, K. Casper, J. C. Locklin, Alec. Gault, Dan. Baker and to H. D. Shearer and Wm. H. Kilroy Officers who were killed in line of duty.... Second plaque (on floor of porch): This building dedicated to Truth-Liberty-Toleration by the Native Sons of the Golden West June 19,1937.Third plaque dedicated 1987 by Native Sons of the Golden West: U. S. Constitution. 1787 Bicentennial Nevada City. A Bicentennial Community. Fourth plaque dedicated 2000 by Nevada City Council: On February 14, 2000 a contract was executed, authorizing the completion of work that began in 1937. On that date, the City Council inaugurated a process by which a small, historically significant City Hall was transformed into a spacious and efficient public facility. Expansion and renovation have been fruitful to the original architectural style and designed to serve the community far in to the 21st century.... Dedicated to all who came before us and all who will follow. Fifth plaque dedicated 2000 by Nevada City Council: On the occasion of the dedication of a new City Hall at this location on December 19, 2000, the citizens and City Council of Nevada City humbly submit for posterity a time capsule secured in a concrete vault beneath this marker. Contained within are artifacts and documents representative of life in Nevada City as we prepare to embrace the uncharted future. We respectfully request this repository remain undisturbed until April 17, 2150, at which time Nevada City will celebrate its 300th birthday.

name: The Flagg Building
mission_description: The Flagg Bldg. The Eternal Saloon. Built in 1856 on the site of the U.S. Hotel, this brick edifice has served Nevada City as the council chamber, Schreiber's, and since 1957 Eddie Furano's Bank Club. Here at Schreiber’s Felix, the marvelous, mysterious music box thundered Strauss waltzes and 'Carmen' to generations with custom and good cheer.

name: National Exchange Hotel
mission_description: Originally the Bicknell Block, stagecoach, mail, express and telegraph center in mining days. Companies which became the Pacific Gas & Electric formed here. Site of first whipping post in state. Facade unchanged since 1854. This hotel, one of the oldest in continuous operation west of the Rockies, opened for business in August, 1856. Originally known as the 'Bicknell Block,' the structure consists of three common-walled buildings of simple brick construction embellished with classic revival and wrought iron railing ornamentation.

name: Ladies of the Evening
address: Under oak tree in National Hotel parking lot on Broad St, Nevada City
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 1972 by Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus: To commemorate that ubiquitous segment of society who have been unacknowledged; who though obscure, made an essential contribution to the settlement of the West. Note: That segment of society made its contribution in the block of Spring Street that runs behind the hotel.

name: Powell House
address: Southeast corner Pine and Spring Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Built in 1855 as the edifice of the Baptist Church. It was here that famed soprano Emma Nevada (Emma Wixom Palmer) made her debut at the age of three. In 1886 the church was remodeled as the residence of the E. T. R. Powell family. Note: The building now houses apartments.

name: Miners Foundry
mission_description: Miners' Foundry (AllanÍs Machine Shop) Founded 1856. This original brick building in continuous usage as a Foundry for over 100 years. Famous Pelton waterwheel developed and manufactured here in 1878. Ingenious double-cupped bucket design by Lester A. Pelton of Camptonville and Nevada City. It became the basis for hydro-electric turbine generators throughout the world. Second plaque dedicated 1994 by State of California: Pelton Wheel Manufacturing Site. The Pelton Water Wheel, first commercially manufactured at George AllanÍs Foundry & Machine Works in 1879 was a major advancement in water power and revolutionized hard rock mining technology. Its unique feature was a series of paired buckets, shaped like bowls or spoons and separated by a splitter, that divided the incoming water into two parts. By the late 1800s, the Pelton Wheels were providing energy to operate water powered machinery throughout the world. In 1888, Lester Pelton moved his business to San Francisco, but granted continuing manufacturing rights to AllanÍs Foundry, where the wheels were manufactured into the early 1900s, when most local mines shifted to electric power.  Note: Opened in 1855, the foundry was moved to its present location after the fire of 1856, and supplied equipment to the milling shops of many mines. Notable equipment included the Patent Mill Guide installed at the Tonopah Mine in Nevada and a gadget known as the Miners Foundry Ejector that had universal demand. Edward Matteson's hydraulic derrick, used to extract rocks from streams and rivers, was perfected here. Much of our modern electricity comes from generators driven by descendants of the Pelton Wheel. Occupied in the 1970s and 1980s by the American Victorian Museum, the building now houses the Miners Foundry Cultural Center.

name: William Morris Stewart House
mission_description: William Morris Stewart Mansion Built 1855-56. Exact replica of wifeÍs ante-bellum colonial birthplace. Only edifice of this type in California. Stewart, an early Nevada County district attorney, joined the 1859 Comstock silver rush, led battle for statehood and became Nevada’s first U.S. Senator. Served 29 years known as the Silver Senator and Father of American mining law. Authored 15th Constitutional Amendment. Note: The Stewart family occupied the home for only a short time before selling the house in 1857 to Judge Niles Searls, whose family lived here from 1858 to 1862.

name: Trinity Episcopal Church
address: Corner of Nevada and High Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: Trinity Episcopal Church. Founded as a parish in 1855, opened for Divine Service in this building on November 2, 1873. Previously on this site was ‘Caldwell's Upper Store' built in 1849 for the miners of Upper Deer Creek Dry Diggings, now known as Nevada City, and Washington School, 1863, the community’s first high school. The present building was erected by shipwrights working in the mines. Their craftsmanship may be seen in its construction. Notes: CaldwellÍs Upper Store and Deer Creek Dry Diggings were the original names for the mining community that became Nevada City. In 1856 W. H. Orr built a brick house here that was used as a public high school from 1862 to 1869. The house was removed in 1871, two years before Trinity Church was built.

name: Charles Marsh House
mission_description: Built about 1866 by Charles Marsh, who arrived here in July, 1849, in what would later become Nevada City. Marsh was the first County Surveyor and the first County Supervisor from Nevada City. He created the water distribution system which formed the basis for P.G.& E. and the Nevada Irrigation District. Marsh was influential in the routing of the Central Pacific Railroad and served on its original Board of Directors, as well as the Board of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. He was also instrumental in creating a Library Association in Nevada City.

name: Colley House
mission_description: Queen Anne Style Built in 1860 Home of Ida Colley and niece, Winifred Mulloy, founders of Laurel Parlor #6 Native Daughters of the Golden West. Now Deer Creek Inn Bed & Breakfast.

name: Plaza Grocery
mission_description: This store, opened in 1882 by Tom Shurtleff, contained the only water-powered elevator in Nevada County. Longest continuous operation of any Nevada City grocery until it closed in 1973. Note: Building was a boarding house from 1880 to 1882. Celio family bought it in 1910 and leased to Scheemers in 1928. John Sbaffi bought the business in 1949 and purchased the building in 1965. It was a grocery until 1973, when 'The Jacks' leased it for use as a restaurant. It has been used primarily as a bar or restaurant since.

name: Nevada Brewery
address: Corner Sacramento and Boulder Sts, Nevada City
mission_description: The Old Brewery. Constructed of granite blocks from the Sierras about 1882. Where Simon C. Hieronimus & family brewed and served lager beer to Nevada City, Queen of the Northern Mines and hydraulic mining communities. Note: This brewery was erected on the site of Temperance Hall after that building burned. After his brewery on Searls Avenue (See 102) burned in 1893, Simon Hieronimus brewed his beer in this building until he died in 1911.

name: Allen Chapman House
mission_description: Allen Chapman House Built in 1856. The home and dental office of Allen Chapman, Nellie Chapman, and their son C. W. Chapman. Nellie Pooler Chapman was the first woman licensed to practice dentistry in the western United States.

name: The Red Castle
mission_description: Nevada City’s earliest surviving brick home, built in 1860 by Judge John Williams, mine owner, businessman and civic leader, who with his family, crossed the plains in 1849. Near ruin, this house was restored by James Wade Schaar in 1963. The Red Castle stands today as a proud reminder of the part the Argonauts played in the Heritage of California.

name: Memorial Grove Nevada City
address: Max Solaro Dr, Pioneer Park, Nevada City
mission_description: This grove honors those who served our country in the armed forces. It contains five plaques.Plaque dedicated 1946 by the citizens of Nevada City: This plot of land set aside by the City of Nevada, these trees living tributes to our war dead. This plaque and flag pole erected by the citizens of Nevada City dedicated July 4, 1946 to the memory of our heroes who gave their lives in World War II that the American way of life may continue. Caswell Fisher, Tevis Ferguson, Merton Downey, Donald Osrey, Bert Graham, Fred Doby, Eugene Davies, Albert Conti, Ernest Chapman, William G. Bennett, Hans G. Hirsef, Clifford M. Ruth, Timothy R. Livesay, Virgil Roseborough, David McCreary, Eugene Rickard, Robert D. Proctor, Louis G. Netz, Glenn Ponticelli , Walter O. St. John, Carl D. Tobiassen, Gus Wasley, James M. Odegaard, William Pohley, Reid Shurtleff.Plaque dedicated 1990 by Banner Mountain Post No. 2655, Veterans of Foreign Wars: Korea, June 25, 1950 - July 27, 1953, 'The Forgotten War - Remembered.' Let us not forget those Americans who served, those who died and those who still remain on that foreign soil in defense of freedom. As a result of that war: 54,246 Americans were killed 8,177 Americans are missing in action 389 Americans are prisoners of war.Plaque dedicated 1992 by Banner Mountain Post No. 2655, Veterans of Foreign Wars: Vietnam. All gave some - some gave all. If you are able, save for them a place inside of you and save one, backward glance when you are leaving for the places they can no longer, go. Be not ashamed to say you loved them, though you may or may not, have always. Take what they have left and what they have taught you, with their dying and keep it with your own. And in that time when men, decide and feel safe to call the war insane, take one moment to, embrace those gentle heroes you left behind. - Major Michael Davis O'Donnell, 1 January 1970, Dak To, Vietnam. Note: Major O'Donnell was a helicopter pilot. On 24 March 1970, while attempting to rescue eight soldiers, his chopper was shot down. He and, three crew members were declared missing in action. This memorial plaque is dedicated as a tribute to those who served and fought in the Vietnam War, especially those who died, and those yet to return. Plaque dedicated 1995 by Banner Mountain Post No. 2655, Veterans of Foreign Wars: POW MIA You are not forgotten.Plaque dedicated 2007 by the citizens of Nevada County: War on Terror  We Will not Forget.In honor of the Men and Women who have served and will serve in the ongoing Global War on Terror and to those Valiant Few who have given their lives, therein... . We, the citizens of Nevada County, dedicate this memorial. L/Cpl Adam Strain, 20, L/Cpl John 'J.T.' Lucente, 19, 1st Lt. Nathan Krisoff, 25, Cpl Sean Stokes, 24, Ssg David P. Senft, 27.There are also memorial plaques for the following Vietnam veterans located on the following Golden Center Freeway overpasses around Nevada City.PfcUSA: Philip A.
