Goeller 06/2/1948-06/01/1969, east end Sacramento StCapt USA: John Stuart Seeley 04/10/1932-06/27/1966, west end Gold Flat Rd1st Lt USA: James F

name: Isabel Hefelfinger Wagon Shed
address: Max Solaro Dr, Pioneer Park, Nevada City
mission_description: The Wagon Shed. Generations of Californians living in the northern mines depended for their economics and social well-being on wheel transportation powered by the horse, mule, the ox. The vehicles displayed here represent some of those used to move people, goods and gold. The Nevada County Historical Society, Hydraulic Parlor No. 56, City of Nevada City, California Department of Parks & Recreation, Nevada City Lions Club and many other civic groups and individuals cooperated to preserve this collection.Second plaque dedicated 1993 by the Historical Society: Isabel Hefelfinger Wagon Shed. This building is dedicated to the memory of Isabel Ross Hefelfinger (1899-1991). She encouraged many by her interest and dedication in remembering the past. Her untiring efforts to preserve history of Nevada County will not be forgotten.

name: Martin Luther Marsh House
mission_description: Martin Luther Marsh arrived in Nevada City in 1851 after a journey from Ohio by the Nicaragua route. He worked as a carpenter, left to mine at Iowa Hill and finally returned to enter the lumber business. With his brother Dan he set up a saw mill on Little Deer Creek (now Pioneer Park). The enterprise boomed and in 1873 Marsh built this magnificent home using carefully seasoned sugar pine for the interior woodwork. His granddaughter Lucille and her late husband James B. Christie restored the house in 1955.

name: American Hill Diggings
mission_description: On this site in 1853 Edward E. Matteson developed one of the first hydraulic mines, an operation in which gold was washed from great quantities of earth with high pressure streams of water. The method used here became a standard of the mining industry through out the world.Second plaque dedicated 2006 by Native Sons of the Golden West: The Hydraulic Monitor, Pipe & Gate Valve displayed here was installed by Native Sons of the Golden West, Hydraulic Parlor 56, Nevada City, January 2006. Note: The first approach to hydraulic mining may have been that of Antoine Chabot, said to have used water to direct gravel into the sluicebox at Buckeye Hill in 1852. But Matteson fully developed the system in 1853 by attaching a nozzle to a rawhide hose to wash down soil for gold recovery at American Hill. By the 1860s Nevada County miners universally credited Matteson with the invention of hydraulic mining and other labor-saving devices.

name: Boardman House
mission_description: Notable as one of the earliest recorded houses in Nevada City and for its history of prominent owners. The tradition that the legendary William Morris Stewart built the house in 1853 cannot be documented for no deeds remain earlier than 1858. However, the house appears as the residence of P. G. Womack in the first map of the city prepared in 1855 and published in 1856. Other owners included the famous mining engineer, Capt. Thos. Mein, whose son William Wallace Mein was born in the house in 1873. The family of the late U.S. Representative Harry Englebright purchased the house in 1897 and resided there until 1959. The interior shows the work of many occupants and the exterior reflects eclectic borrowings from many past styles.

name: Robinson Plaza
address: Foot of Main St, Nevada City. The plaza is dedicated to Beryl Robinson and contains several  sites and plaques.
mission_description: Robinson Plaza named for Beryl  Robinson Jr.  Born in Nevada City September 13, 1935. City Councilman-City Manager. On July 1,1999, Beryl Robinson Jr. became the longest-serving City Manager in state history. A native of the town he has so ably served, Beryl was appointed City Manager on June 21, 1965. In addition to being Nevada City's chief administrative and financial official, he has diligently worked to preserve the community's 19th-century spirit and buildings, including the two historic structures here at Robinson Plaza. Beryl's continuing career in public service has already spanned the terms of seven presidents, six governors and three-dozen council members. A Mason, Rotarian and Elk, Beryl has brought a sense of commitment and purpose two his life matched by few and bettered by none.

name: Calanan Park
address: Corner Broad and Union Sts, Nevada City. This small park is dedicated to George Calanan and contains several historical objects and plaques.
mission_description: Text of plaque: Native Daughters Garden in George Calanan Park. In 1922, Laurel Parlor No. 6, Native Daughters of the Golden West acquired two small lots to create a memorial park for the veterans and those who died in World War I. In the interest of 'a valuable public improvement,' Laurel Parlor sold the lot to the U.S. Forest Service for a district office in 1936. The advent of World War II redirected federal resources and the planned 6,000 square foot building was never constructed. The lot remained a community park. In 1967, the park was dedicated to honor George Humphrey Calanan (1872- 1951), a much-loved Town Trustee (City Councilman), health officer, assessor, volunteer fireman, and long time City Clerk. He was known as 'the man who got things done.' The park was granted to the City of Nevada City by the United States Department of the Interior on December 1, 1971.

name: Hydraulic Gate Valve
mission_description: Hydraulic gold mining 21-inch gate valve 1880 Used at the You Bet-Red Dog Diggin's east of Nevada City periodically 1880- 1935 to control water flow from Chalk Bluff reservoir to the mine. Hydraulic nozzle mounted opposite was operated at that mine by Thomas B. Brady. Manufactured by Joshua Handy Works, San Francisco. Wt. 1,500 lbs. approx.  A gift from the Brady Family.

name: Nevada City Masonic Lodge
mission_description: The year was 1850 at a location not far from here. The first Masonic Lodge meeting was held under a Charter from state of Wisconsin. Lafayette Lodge #29  was born, the years following in 1851 & 1863 a major part of which was to be known as Nevada City was destroyed by fires. By this time California was a State and a new Lodge of California Charter was established as Nevada #13 F&AM in 1851. At this location the first masonry structure was built in 1852 as a store. The 1863 fire destroyed this building and again the Lodge at a different place. This site was purchased for $1,650 and rebuilt as a store with Lodge rooms up stairs. The Lodge moved in 1864. A dining room/office extension was built to the right in 1901. Over the past 136 years other Masonic units/orders have also been meeting here. Royal Arch, Nevada Chapter #6,  Council #62, K. T Commandery #6, Evangeline Eastern Star #9. In honor of 150 years continuous Nevada Lodge #13 F&AM  Masonic Actives.  Grand Master of California Alvin J. Weis placed this plaque in rededication of this Lodge April 22, 2000.  Note: The plaque is quoted verbatim; all errors are in the original.

name: 400 Broad Street
mission_description: Text of plaque: It was at this location on the afternoon of June 5, 1880 that a fire erupted in John White's upholstery shop. More than fifty buildings - including the nearby New York Hotel and most of the Chinese Quarter - were destroyed within an hour, but from the ashes of that conflagration a new business district emerged and York Street was created to ensure better downtown fire protection.  Then, early in the 20th century, a doctor's office was established here. The longest-serving physician to occupy this corner was Bernard W. Hummelt, MD (1906 - 1998), who, between 1934 and his retirement in 1988, practiced internal medicine, orthopedics and general surgery. Over the course of his lengthy career he delivered over 1500 Nevada County babies. Dr. Hummelt was among the earliest physicians in the nation to administer penicillin and was instrumental in the founding of Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital - where he served as its third Chief of Staff. Placed by the family of Bernard W. Hummelt, M.D. to honor the centennial of Dr. Hummelt's birth August 5,1906 A remarkable life- an exemplary career.

name: Lindeboom Memorial
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 1986 by Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 2655: Dedicated to the memory of Tina Lindeboom March 1911-February 1984. With gratitude and appreciation of the American people for gallant service in assisting Allied soldiers escape from the enemy W.W. II 1939-1945.

name: English and New Salmon Mine Stamp Mill
address: Miners Foundry, 325 Spring St, Nevada City
mission_description: This stamp mill was manufactured at the Miners Foundry and Supply Co., Nevada City, California, in the late 1800’s. After a circuitous journey, it has returned to its place of origin. It started its industrial life of crushing hard rock at the English Mine, and then the New Salmon Mine, owned by Donald McPherson, at Badger Hill. The stamp mill ceased operation in 1942 when all non-critical gold mines were shut down. After sitting idle through the years overgrown by trees and brush the stamp mill was moved in the 1970’s to the Nevada City home of King McPherson, who generously donated the stamp mill back to the Miners Foundry in the 1980’s. The stamp mill sat in pieces around the foundry, despite several attempts to reconstruct it. Through the efforts of the members of Hydraulic Parlor No. 56, Native Sons of the Golden West under the supervision of Mike Nevius, restoration was completed in the spring of 2000.

name: Pine Street Crossing at Nevada City
address: S. Pine St at Deer Creek, Nevada City
mission_description: Pine Street Bridge 1996. Third span of Deer Creek at this location. It is a replica of the single arch steel Gault bridge (1903-1996) which replaced the suspension bridge (1862-1903) built by Andrew S. Hallidie, who later built the San Francisco cable car system. Note: The bridge is officially named the South Pine Street Bridge at Hallidie Crossing. Hallidie's patented structure collapsed two weeks after it opened, killing two men. The Gault bridge, similar to the one at Edwards Crossing (No. 128) was named for Nevada City Mayor Alexander Gault.

name: Weiss-Hieronimus Brewery Cellar
mission_description: The Weiss-Hieronimus Brewery Cellar. Beginning in the early 1860s and continuing until Prohibition, the lower portion of this building was the storeroom for keg beer produced first by Emille (sic) Weiss for the Weiss Brewery then by Simon Hieronimus for the Hieronimus Brewery_later known as the Nevada Brewery. As the brewery business grew, Mr. Hieronimus established a bottling plant and stable on property across the street from this building. But keg beer continued to be stored here. A fire in the summer of 1896 destroyed the original house and severely damaged the cellar. But the Nevada Brewery emerged bigger and better than ever. It was at that time that the cellar was enlarged to its present size, a ventilation system installed and refrigeration added. In 2004 the property was acquired by Jesse and Kay Connor, who carefully restored the old brewery cellar and home. This plaque has been placed to honor the legacy of both the Weiss and Hieronimus families and to remind people that the best lager beer in Nevada County was once produced here. Note: Messrs Weiss and Hieronimus were each born in France. Weiss arrived in Nevada City in 1850 and immediately opened a brewery. Hieronimus arrived in Nevada City in 1876, then operated a brewery in North Bloomfield before taking over this brewery.

name: Hunt's Hill (Gouge Eye)
address: About 6 m. east of Nevada City, off Buckeye Rd, about 1 m. from the intersection with Red Dog Rd
mission_description: Hunt's Hill (also Gouge Eye) is a former mining camp founded in 1852 by a miner named Hunt. It was located on one of the deepest parts of the rich Blue Lead channel of gold-bearing gravel. In 1855, one of the mining claims established by some French miners, was “jumped.” During the fight, one of the French miners lost an eye. Thereafter, that mine, and sometimes the town, were called Gouge Eye. By 1857, the town boasted two saloons, a hotel, a blacksmith and stable, a butcher shop, a boot and shoe store, and several grocery stores. In 1858, a stage line from Nevada City arrived. By 1880, the town was reduced to a combined store and saloon and a few houses. Today, there are some private homes in the area but the old mining camp is just a historic site.

name: Sheriff David Fulton Douglass
address: Just past 15934 Airport Rd, 3/4 m. from junction with Lake Vera Rd, Nevada City
mission_description: On this spot Sheriff Douglass, a Native Son of the Golden West, gave his life July 26, 1896, bravely performing his duty. Alone he tracked a highwayman to this retreat and both fell In battle. It is believed Douglass was pitted against two and that one escaped. The bodies lay parallel. Nearby is a second plaque identifying the spot where the bandit lay.

name: Purdon Crossing Bridge
address: Bottom of Purdon Rd at South Fork of Yuba River, north of Nevada City
mission_description: Purdon Bridge 1895. Built by Cotton Brothers of Oakland, this steel bridge replaced several wooden bridges washed away in floods. It is the only bridge of the half-through truss design remaining in California. Purdon Crossing was a vital link of the main road from Nevada City to Downieville and the Northern Mines. Note: The unique quality of a half-through truss is that the deck is carried halfway between the top and bottom of the support structure; very few were built in California. First bridge at this site was built by William E. Robinson in 1854. In 1859 John Webber dismantled Robinson's Bridge and replaced it. Webber's Bridge washed away in December 1861 and was replaced by a rope suspension foot bridge in February 1862. Jesse Wall bought the foot bridge and crossing in the spring of 1862 and built a new bridge that summer. Wall sold it to James M. Black in 1864. Peter Purdon bought the bridge in 1870 and sold it to the county in 1890, which replaced it with this one in 1895.

name: North San Juan Fire Department
address: 10057 Reservoir St, North San Juan, off Hwy 49
mission_description: First Fire Department. To the memory of the first fire department, organized 1862, George Murphy, first fire chief. Note: The building is now a community hall.

name: North San Juan
address: In North San Juan on front of Bigley's Market, Hwy 49
mission_description: North San Juan 1853. Dedicated to the memory of the founder Christian Keinz and to all the pioneer argonauts of San Juan Ridge, who by their labor and fortitude contributed so greatly to the wealth and economy of Nevada County, California and the nation.

name: Wells Fargo Building, North San Juan
address: Corner of Flume St and Hwy 49, North San Juan
mission_description: Wells Fargo & Company 1854. Office and holding center for gold and currency, 1854-60. Block & Furth Co. Clothing Store, 1861-69. Chinese Laundry and store operated by Happy Go Lucky, 1890-1920. Bar and liquor store since 1934. First saloon owner, ‘Ma' Cunningham, 1934.

name: Old North San Juan School
address: 29190 Hwy 49, south end of North San Juan
mission_description: The first school building on this site was moved from Flume Street in 1869. It burned in 1924, and this building was moved here from Lake Vera. This site operated as a school from 1869 until 1984. It is currently used as a community center and library.

name: North San Juan Methodist Episcopal Church
address: End of Flume St off Hwy 49, North San Juan
mission_description: Erected in 1857 at a cost of $1500, the structure Is the earliest existing church in the county. It contains early furnishings. Second plaque dedicated 1980 by the church board and Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus: North San Juan United Methodist Church 1856. One of the oldest of its faith in continuous operation in California. Escaped three major fires which destroyed the town. The Rev. H. B. Sheldon, first assigned pastor, rode circuit from Brandy City to French Corral on horseback.

name: Blue Tent
address: About 5 miles northeast of Nevada City, approximately at the intersection of N. Bloomfield and Blue Tent School Rds
mission_description: Blue Tent is a historic mining community established in 1850 and named after its first dwelling, a tent made of blue denim. In its heyday, it had a population of over 350, and its own store, dancehall, blacksmith shop, boarding house and other buildings.  A non-denominational Union Church was erected in 1861, and a school was established in 1868. A substantial Chinatown existed just north of  Blue Tent. The community was connected by stage to Nevada City, and by the world's first long distance telephone line established in 1878, to the mining communities around the San Juan Ridge. A post office existed between 1878 and 1889. In addition to mining, Blue Tent for many years had a thriving industry harvesting ice and shipping it throughout California. Like many communities that depended on hydraulic mining, Blue Tent began to decline following the 1884 Sawyer decision, forbidding the discharge of mining debris into the Yuba River. As mining declined, agriculture began to predominate. Today, the Blue Tent district is a pleasant, rural, largely residential area. Not much evidence remains of the mining district, except the Blue Tent school, which is still at the site to which it was moved in 1892. It has been converted to a private residence, but remains painted a vivid blue.

name: Pioneer Emigrant Trail (II)
address: 10867 Coyote St, near North Bloomfield Rd, Nevada City
mission_description: A branch of the Pioneer Emigrant Trail leading from Truckee Pass to the gold mines of Nevada County traversed Harmony Ridge down through this gap and on to the Valley of the Sacramento.

name: Pioneer Emigrant Trail (I)
address: On Airport Rd about 100 feet from junction with Lake Vera Rd, Nevada City
mission_description: A branch of the Pioneer Emigrant Trail leading from Truckee Pass to the gold mines of Nevada County and to the Valley of the Sacramento divided on Harmony Ridge near the site of Lone Grave. One route circled the north horizon to Blue Tent, down to Selby Flat, up through this gap and on south.

name: Cherokee
address: North of Nevada City on Tyler Foote Rd, about 5 miles east of Hwy 49, just past Sages Rd
mission_description: Cherokee is a former gold mining community In Nevada County, located on the San Juan Ridge about 4 miles east of North San Juan. At the time of the Gold Rush, this area was occupied by the Nisenan. The Gold Rush came to Cherokee in 1850, when a group of Cherokee Indians began mining there and gave it its name. The town's heyday was between 1856 and 1865. It had two hotels, the Grizzly and Curnow’s, saloons, several stores, a butcher, a shoe shop, a resident physician and drugstore, and a blacksmith. Its sawmill had a capacity of 10,000 ft. of lumber a day. The local newspaper was the Cherokee Journal. There was stagecoach service to Nevada City. After 1878, Cherokee was connected to the world’s first long distance telephone line which connected the mining communities along the San Juan Ridge from French Corral to the Bowman Lake area. The town began to decline in the 1880’s, after hydraulic mining was restricted by the Sawyer decision. By 1924, the town was reduced to "one store; and the people live principally by farming, very little active mining being carried on here." Today, all that remains of Cherokee is the schoolhouse located on Sages Road just north of Tyler Foote Crossing Road, the historic cemetery, and a lot of land scarred by hydraulic mining.

name: Edwards Crossing Bridge
address: On North Bloomfield Rd at South Fork of Yuba River, northeast of Nevada City
mission_description: Built in 1904 by the American Bridge Company of steel-connection-pin design to replace a wooden structure built in 1862 by William Edwards. In 1854 Edwards began operations here with a ferry, and in 1855 he built a bridge and toll road between Blue Tent and Lake City. His first bridge washed away in December 1861, and was replaced in the following year. The county acquired the bridge sometime after 1880. Note: Both this and the similar Gault bridge at Nevada City (No. 99) were built under the supervision of Nevada County Surveyor W. W. Waggoner.

name: Columbia Hill School
address: Tyler Foote Rd, San Juan Ridge, 8.7 m. east of Hwy 49, northeast of Nevada City
mission_description: The schoolhouse, built in 1875, was still in use as a school in the 1970's. In 1980 the State of California condemned the schoolhouse as unsafe. It was remodeled and used for a while as a community center. Later a new community center was established next door, and the old school building was used for other purposes. It is now known as the North Columbia Schoolhouse Cultural Center. The original Columbia Hill School was built prior to March 11,1867.

name: Foote's Crossing Road
address: From intersection of Cruzon Grade and Tyler-Foote Rds in Nevada County to Alleghany in Sierra County (See Note on access below)
mission_description: Foote’s Crossing Road was built by A. D. Foote in 1913 as an all-season short-cut from Columbia Hill to the mines of the Alleghany area. Foote was president of the Tightner Mine Co., the largest gold producer in the region at that time. The road, a 15-foot shelf hanging on the sheer canyon wall above the Middle Fork of the Yuba River, is a spectacular engineering feat and scenic wonder. The rock walls, built without mortar are still intact today. Unforeseen difficulties in building the road caused it to far exceed specifications so Foote personally financed 60% of the total cost, the balance being paid by Nevada and Sierra counties and the U.S. Forest Service.

name: North Bloomfield Mining & Gravel  Co.
address: Malakoff Diggins State Park; 0.8 m. west of North Bloomfield on No. Bloomfield Rd
mission_description: Landmark registered 1972 by State of California, CHL 852. Plaque dedicated 1972 by State in cooperation with Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus and Malakoff Citizens Advisory Committee: This was a major hydraulic operation in California. Its vast system of canals and flumes using a drainage tunnel 7800 feet long was termed a feat of engineering skill. It was the principal defendant in an anti-debris lawsuit settled by the Sawyer decision in 1884. SawyerÍs famous decision created controls that virtually ended hydraulic mining in California. Note on access: Park at Diggins Loop Trail Access and follow arrow to Scenic Overlook. To see plaque, take trail about 25 feet east of "No Dogs On Trail" sign. Plaque is about 300 feet from road. Note on Access: Over the 3 m. on either side of the Yuba, this road is narrow, steep, twisting and potentially hazardous. A high-clearance, four wheel drive vehicle is recommended.

name: Saint Columncille's Catholic Church
address: No. Bloomfield Rd, west of North Bloomfield, Malakoff Diggins State Park
mission_description: The original plaque disappeared and was replaced in 1949 by Native Daughters of the Golden West by a wooden plaque: St. Columncille’s Catholic Church. Formerly the Bridgeport Union Guard Hall, was used in 1860 to train men for the Civil War under Capt. Frank Coffey of French Corral. In 1880, it was purchased as a house of worship for the Catholics of the ridge towns. Note: This building formerly was located at Birchville. In 1969 it was purchased by Babe Pinaglia and given to Malakoff Diggins Park, where it occupies the site of the Catholic Church that once served the miners of North Bloomfield.

name: North Bloomfield School
address: North side No. Bloomfield Rd, west end of North Bloomfield
mission_description: North Bloomfield School 1872-73. Built at a cost of some 3,000 dollars. Modeled after schoolhouses at nearby Sebastopol and Sweetland, it served the community until closed in 1941. Acquired from Washington School District, Nevada County, for public use and display. Restoration commenced in 1973 by popular subscription.

name: Malakoff Diggins Clampicnic Area
address: Malakoff Diggins State Park, No. Bloomfield Rd just west of the old Grand Central Hote
mission_description: This picnic area, sponsored by the Wm. Bull Meek-Wm. Morris Stewart Chapter No. 10 E Clampus Vitus, is for the enjoyment of all. The redwood lumber for the tables came from Nevada City’s Christmas Tree, a Sequoiadendron Giganteum, and continues to serve the residents and visitors of Nevada County.

name: Malakoff Diggins --North Bloomfield Historic District
address: Malakoff Diggins State Historic Park, No. Bloomfield Rd, 11 m. from Nevada City
mission_description: Site of the worldÍs largest hydraulic gold mining operation. The North Bloomfield Mining Company purchased approximately 1500 acres near the settlement of Malakoff in 1866. Hydraulic mining exposed the area to enormous amounts of high pressure water through nozzles called 'monitors.' The application of pressurized water on the mountainsides of Malakoff left a 1600 acre pit 7000 feet long by 3000 feet wide. The awesome effects of the world’s largest hydraulic gold mining operation are still visible today. Note: According to historian Robert Wyckoff the La Grange Mine near Weaverville was larger.

name: Shoot (Chute) Hill
address: Across from space 29 in Chute Hill campground about 7/10 m. east of North Bloomfield
mission_description: Local historians relate that water from high mountain lakes flowed thru a 500' wooden 'chute' which led to a huge square tank or pressure box behind campsite 29. Here it entered a 3' pipe reduced to gain pressure to 2', then down hill 200' to the hydraulic monitors at the mine.

name: Lone Grave
address: Hwy 20, 8 m. east of Nevada City
mission_description: Julius Albert Apperson Born June 1855-Died May 6,1858. A pioneer who crossed the plains to California who died and was buried here. The Emigrant Trail followed along this ridge and through Nevada City. The marking of this lone grave perpetuates the memory of all lone graves throughout the state of California. Plaque incorrectly identifies this Landmark as NEV 001. Note: Julius Apperson was not a passerby. The boy died as the result of burns sustained on his parents' ranch and he was buried on Apperson property. The original date on the grave was May 31,1858. There are two white wooden grave markers nailed to trees behind the fenced-in gravesite. One says "In memory of Julius Albert Apperson, died May 6, 1858, age 2 years, 2 mos., 25 days." The other contains the boy's initials and dates. A gravestone on the ground inside the fence reads: In Loving Memory of Julius Albert Apperson, Died May 6, 1858, Age 2 yrs, 2 mos, 25 days." However, if that was his true age he would have been born in February 1856 instead of June 1855, as the plaque states. References; (1) Testimony of John Milton Apperson, a Tehama County cattleman and older brother of Julius, on February 25, 1936; (2) "Lone Graves of Nevada County" in the Nevada County Historical Society Bulletin, January 1961; (3) an item in the Nevada Democrat, May 5, 1858, stating that the child was terribly burned near the house where he lived on April 30.

name: La Grange Giant
address: Location: Next to museum in N. Bloomfield
mission_description: This monitor was used at the now closed La Grange mine near Weaverville in Trinity County and is similar in size to those used at the Malakoff to wash down the gravel hillsides. Note: Historians still disagree over which mine was larger; the La Grange or the North Bloomfield.

name: Alvin Stevens Trivelpiece
address: At Diggins Overlook in Chute Hill campground about 7/10 m. east of North Bloomfield
mission_description: Alvin Stevens Trivelpiece 1903-1967. Californian, Clamper, Nevada County Historian, Newspaperman, Friend and a Founding Father of the Malakoff State Park, in whose memory these benches were placed.

name: Relief Hill
address: South of intersection of Relief Hill Rd and Relief Hill Mine Rd, about 5 m. east of North Bloomfield
mission_description: Note: Access to the old townsite and historic cemetery is sometimes restricted by the US Forest Service.  Description: Relief Hill dates from 1853. By 1856, it had a population of 75, two saloons, one store, one butcher shop, one blacksmith shop, two boarding houses and several homes. In 1858, registered voters alone numbered 100. Its decline followed the Sawyer decision enjoining certain aspects of hydraulic mining. In the early 1900s, some residents moved closer to Relief Hill Road. Some of those buildings can still be seen. While there is still some intermittent mining in the area, by the 1960s, the old townsite was largely deserted. Not much but the cemetery remains.

name: Graniteville
address: No. Bloomfield-Graniteville Rd, across from house at No. 35177. 50 ft past gazebo bearing Graniteville sign.
mission_description: A camp established in this area in 1850 was called Eureka; then later, Eureka South. By 1856 it sometimes had a winter population of 1000. Rich placer mining deposits were played out by 1865, but quartz mining continued. By 1867, total gold taken from this area was estimated at 20 million dollars. Area also important as distribution point for water from reservoirs, fed to hydraulic mines below by ditches. Name changed to Graniteville when Post Office was established on Aug. 26, 1867.

name: Summit City/Meadow Lake
address: Meadow Lake Rd, south of Jackson Meadows Rd
mission_description: In June of 1863, the trapper Henry Hartley discovered gold bearing ore here and staked out the Excelsior Company claims. Exaggerated reports and a 1865 market panic in the Comstock mines of Virginia City brought thousands of miners overnight to the supposed 'Little Comstock' of Summit City. Within two years an incorporated town, renamed Meadow Lake grew to encompass 160 acres with 4,000 summer residents and over 500 buildings, including 200 business houses, a stock exchange, daily newspaper, Post Office, school, 6 breweries and 80 saloons. Streets were laid out grid fashion, with a 9,000 square foot plaza on the lakeshore. An excursion vessel ferried revelers to four hurdy-gurdy houses at the lake’s upper end. The winter of 1866-1867 brought 30 feet of snow with the 'Snowshoe Express' delivering mail through Cisco. In all the eight stamp mills in a district of 10,910 claims failed to extract the expected gold from its 'Rebellious Ore.' The optimism faded and the town declined with like rapidity. July of 1869 found 60 residents. By 1873 only Hartley 'The Hermit' remained. His grave is on a hillside to the west of town. A wooden sign nearby was erected at an unknown date by Troop 40, Kentfield-Marin Council, Boy Scouts of America: Meadow Lake-Excelsior. The granite dam was built 1858 for flumes of valley gold towns. Called Summit City with 2000 pop. after 1866. It incorporated as Meadow Lake 1866. Because gold could not be separated it was abandoned 1872.

name: Emigrant Trail to Nevada City
address: Washington Ridge Vista Point, Hwy 20, 0.2 m. west of Washington Rd
mission_description: In 1850, the year after the fabulous gold strike on Deer Creek in Nevada City, the Overland Emigrant Trail branched off the original Bear River route at this point on its way to Nevada City and the Sacramento Valley. Soon thereafter the trail became a toll road and later a public road. The deep vehicle ruts can still be seen as they cross and recross Highway 20 many times.

name: Town of Washington
address: Bottom of Washington Rd on South Fork of the Yuba River, 18 m. northeast of Nevada City via Hwy 20
mission_description: Washington, originally Indiana Boys Camp, is a town that refused to ghost. It was settled in 1849. By 1880 miners had recovered over $10,500,000 in gold here. Note: First plaque is on the Washington Hotel. Note: The only mining town in the county not destroyed by fire. Today, Washington (pop. about 180) is one of the few remaining early mining towns. The permanent population swells to hundreds more residents in the summer months. A second plaque, shown above, was dedicated at an unknown date in a small park at the intersection of Washington Rd and Alpha Toll Rd: In August, 1850 Washington was the highest point on the South Yuba River at which gold had been discovered, with over a 1,000 miners. In 1870 the Chinese outnumbered the white population. The last try to strike it rich was in the 1890’s. Washington is the last remaining village of the many that flourished in the Washington Mining District. Historical notes by Robert I. and Grace I. Slyter.

name: Washington Hotel and Site
mission_description: Hessel Buisman built the first hotel on this site in 1857. It was destroyed by fire in August 1867, along with neighboring businesses. Buisman replaced it with a two-story hotel in that same year. In 1887, Buisman's daughter Harminia and her husband, E. T. Worthley, inherited the hotel, which burned in April 1896. The Worthleys reopened it with a third story in August 1896. John J. Rogers bought the hotel in 1910 for $50, and in 1911 he installed a water pipeline across the river to the Nice and Latta ditch to furnish water for the town. In 1912, he used the water to generate the first electricity for the hotel. Thomas B. Williamson, who had purchased a half interest in the hotel for $10 in 1911, bought out Rogers in 1916, and then sold it to Pietro Orzalli. Orzalli sold the property to R. F. Williamson (brother of Tom) in 1925. In 1926, Emory J. Haverstock bought the hotel and added dormer windows on the top floor, using lumber salvaged from the fire-ravaged Dugan Hotel (also in Washington). Haverstock sold it to Clark and Edna Waite for $10 in 1939. In 1955, the hotel was sold for $10 to Harold Moneyhun, former owner of the Holbrooke Hotel in Grass Valley, and Edwin Furano of Nevada City. In 1968, Thomas E. Walsh used siding salvaged from the National Hotel Annex in Nevada City to enclose the side porch on the upriver side of the hotel.

name: Brimskill Building
address: Washington Rd, opposite hotel in town of Washington
mission_description: Built by Edward Brimskill, 1849-1851. Rear section built 1849. Iron shutters a protection from fire and robbers, imported from Scotland. Used in early days as general store and miners supply. Wells Fargo maintained desk room here for many years and shipped thousands of dollars of gold from here. One of the best preserved buildings in California of the gold rush era. Said to be oldest building in Nevada County.

name: Kohler Building
address: Washington Rd, next to hotel in town of Washington
mission_description: Built by Henry Kohler, pioneer merchant and miner born in Germany in 1825. He came to Washington from Indiana in 1854. He mined until 1861 when he opened a general merchandise store to supply groceries, hardware and mining supplies to the area.

name: Washington Elementary School
address: School St in town of Washington
mission_description: 100 Years of uninterrupted use as a California public school. Having survived fires, floods, wars, time, and politics, this school has been doing its part to ensure the rights of American children to receive a basic education.

name: Canyon Creek Bridge Site
address: Maybert Rd at Canyon Creek, 3.3 m. east of town of Washington. Maybert Rd does not require four-wheel-drive but is not advised for cars with low clearance
mission_description: The Canyon Creek Bridge was built in 1895 by Cotton Brothers and Co. of Oakland, California, for $1,725. Completed two years earlier than the Old Auburn Bridge (No. 13,), it is of similar construction and design. Underneath it is the reservoir that supplies water to the residents of the town of Washington. Canyon Creek is a major tributary of the South Yuba River, and the scenic view of the rapids and falls above the bridge is outstanding. Note: After determining the bridge had outlived its useful life, the County erected a modern bridge in 2017 and placed this plaque: Site of a steel pony truss bridge erected in 1895 at Canyon Creek Crossing on the road linking Washington to the town of Maybert. There the Yuba Mine employed 13 Chinese and 27 Americans, one of the few mines still employing Chinese. In the 1880’s and 1890’s Maybert had a Post Office, store, boarding house, school and saloon. Fire destroyed all 20 of its dwellings in 1909. The old bridge was disassembled and is awaiting relocation by Nevada City as part of its hiking trails expansion.

name: Ormonde Town Site
address: Maybert Rd, 3.6 m. east of Washington. About 3/10 m. past Maybert (Canyon Creek) bridge in Golden Quartz campground. Maybert Rd does not require 4-wheel-drive but not advised for cars with low clearance.
mission_description: The town of Ormonde was established here in 1887. Downstream, across the mouth of Canyon Creek was Canyonville 1850, and upriver approximately four miles was Maybert 1886. These towns were part of the upper Washington Mining District and were the furthest upstream of the serious mining ventures along the South Yuba. During its brief history the district yielded 17 million dollars in gold, but by 1897 it was nearly totally abandoned. The remains have since been obliterated by flooding. Note: The town consisted of 8-10 buildings, including a store, saloon and boarding house.

name: Alpha and Omega Hydraulic
address: Hwy 20, About 16 m. east of Nevada City and 10 m. west of I-80 Hwy junction. Near eastern end of restrooms in Omega Rest Area
mission_description: One mile north of here were the towns of Alpha and Omega, named by gold miners in the early 1850’s. The tremendous hydraulic diggings, visible from near this point, engulfed most of the original townsites. Alpha was the birthplace of famed opera singer Emma Nevada. Mining at Omega continued until 1949, and lumbering operations are carried on there today.

name: Gaston
address: Roughly midway between Graniteville and town of Washington, near the intersection of Gaston and Hoosier Rds, in the Tahoe National Forest.
mission_description: A historic mining community. Placer mining around Gaston began in the early 1850’s. The first hard rock mine, the California Mine, was established in 1856. An ample supply of water was ensured by the arrival of the North Bloomfield ditch in 1870. In 1898, the mine, now known as the Gaston Mine, was acquired by the San Francisco based Gaston Gold Mining Company, which substantially upgraded operations. A town blossomed around the mine. The population was recorded as about 200 in 1900. There was stage service to the town of Washington, and to Nevada City. By 1904, the town boasted two stores, a hotel, a saloon, a hardware store, a Post Office, a water system, electric lights, a telephone line to Nevada City, a fire company and a school. The mine closed during World War I, because of a shortage of labor and supplies needed for the war effort. There was intermittent mining after the war. By the 1940s’, the last remaining building was in shambles. Today, nothing readily visible remains of Gaston.

name: Western America Skisport Museum
address: Exit on Boreal Ridge Rd on I-80 west of summit
mission_description: A monument and statue was placed by Snowshoe Thompson Lodge No. 78, Sons of Norway, Yuba City: Snowshoe Thompson. A hero of the Sierra Nevada mountains! Probably the first skier of the West. This Viking Son of Norway exemplified the spirit of a true pioneer: Strong, daring, faithful and courageous. He was the answer to CaliforniaÍs motto, 'Bring me men to match my mountains.' For 20 years he was the winter lifeline between the new state of California and the East with a regular mail schedule between Placerville, California, and Genoa, Nevada, and other isolated hamlets of the Mother Lode country. Mail, news of the world, medicine, supplies and equipment arrived on the sturdy shoulders of this giant Snow Viking over great snowdrifts, through raging winter storms, with packs of up to 100 pounds, he made his 'appointed rounds.' His daring rescues, errands of mercy, and many kindnesses made him a legend in his own time. He was born John Tostensen at Tinn in Telemark, Norway, April 30, 1827. He died May 15, 1876, at the age of 49. He rests at the base of the mountains he loved, by the side of his wife and son in the cemetery at Genoa, Nevada. A simple headstone, engraved with a pair of skis, marks his grave.

name: Trans-Sierra Freeway Project
address: Highway rest stops on both sides of I-80, at Donner Summit, west of Truckee
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 1966 by the American Society of Civil Engineering: Civil Engineering Achievement of Merit, 1966, Awarded by the American Society of Civil Engineers.

name: McGlashan Point
address: Overlook next to Donner Summit Bridge on Donner Pass Rd, Old Hwy 40
mission_description: Dedicated August 10,1986 in honor of Charles Fayette McGlashan 1847-1931. Truckee’s Patriarch, Historian, Author, Editor, Attorney, Legislator, Inventor, Entomologist and Astronomer. His last public address was given in 1926 at the Donner Summit Bridge Dedication. This site is named in his memory by the people of Truckee.

name: Donner Summit Bridge
address: Donner Pass Rd (Old Hwy 40) overlooking Donner Lake
mission_description: First plaque dedicated 1926 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Dedicated to the pioneers who blazed the Overland Trail through these mountains. Built by the U. S. Bureau of Public Roads and the California Highway Commission, 1925-1926. Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1998 by Nevada County: 1926 Donner Summit Bridge Restored 1995. Note: In 1926 it was anticipated that the bridge (built at a cost of about $40,000) would become a popular stopping place on the "Victory Highway." The bridge was designed by Norman C. Raab, whose wife, Ruby Bishop Raab, was the great-granddaughter of Isaac Hitchcock of the Stephens-Townsend-Murphy party. The original bridge arch was 110 feet long and 70 feet high, built on a compound curve, with a seven percent grade. Among those who attended the 1926 ceremony were Charles F. McGlashan and these descendants of Donner party survivors: James Fraser Lewis, Martha Jane Lewis, Susan A. Lewis, and Ernest H. Murphy. Norman Raab also designed the world-famous Bixby Creek Bridge on State Highway 1 at Big Sur, built in 1930-1931.

name: Mt. Elisha Stephens
address: Parking lot next to Donner Summit Bridge on Donner Pass Rd, Old Hwy 40
mission_description: Stephens-Townsend-Murphy Party of 1844 First Pioneer Wagons Over the Sierra Nevada. On May 22, 1844, this small wagon party of 50 men, women and children 'jumped off' from Council Bluffs, Iowa, bound for California. These courageous pioneers were the first emigrants to take wagons over the Sierra Nevada, opening the Truckee Route of the California Trail. The Murphy, Townsend, Miller, and Hitchcock families formed the main groups of the party. Caleb Greenwood was the hired guide, and Elisha Stephens was elected Captain of the wagon train. After following the Oregon Trail to Fort Hall, Idaho, they turned away from the well-worn path and headed west into the unfamiliar Nevada desert. A Paiute Indian Chief showed them how to reach a river flowing from the Sierra Nevada, which they named 'Truckee' in his honor. Overcoming severe conditions, they followed the Truckee River to the base of the Sierra. Six members, on horseback, continued to follow the Truckee River and eventually arrived safely at Sutter's New Helvetia on December 10, 1844. Six of the wagons were left in the charge of two men, and young Moses Schallenberger, near Truckee Lake (present Donner Lake). Near this spot, with two feet of snow on the ground, they worked the remaining five wagons across the summit of the mighty Sierra Nevada on November 25, 1844. Deepening snow forced them to camp near Big Bend, on the South Yuba River. Leaving the wagons with two men and the women and children, the remaining 17 men continued on to New Helvetia to seek help. Somehow, John Sutter persuaded the men to enlist in his forces taking part in a Mexican civil war. Eventually the families were reunited, and all members (including two babies born on the way) arrived safely at Sutter’s Fort in early March 1845. Note: Mount Elisha Stephens is west of bridge on north side of road.

name: China Wall at Donner Summit
address: South side of Donner Pass Rd (Old Hwy 40), west of Donner Lake about 0.5 m. below summit
mission_description: Charles Crocker, construction chief of the Central Pacific Railroad (CPRR), contracted for a workforce of approximately 12,000 Chinese laborers to push the CPRR tracks over its Trans-Sierra crossing on its race east to meet with the Union Pacific at Promontory, Utah Territory. A railroad retaining wall and fill, constructed of Sierra granite, stand silently above on the pass as a lasting monument to these Asian 'Master Builders' who left an indelible mark on the history of California and the West.

name: First Wagons Across the Sierra
address: West end Donner Lake, corner Donner Pass Rd and S. Shore Dr, west of Truckee
mission_description: The Stephens-Townsend-Murphy Party, with guidance from old Caleb Greenwood and Chief Truckee, brought their wagons up the Truckee River bed and on Nov. 25,1844, 191 days out of Council Bluffs, Iowa, passed this point and crossed the mighty Sierra summit directly to the west, blazing the famous California Emigrant Trail for all who followed.

name: Pollard's Station
address: Near intersection of S. Shore Dr and Donner Pass Rd, west of Truckee
mission_description: On this site, Joseph Delos Pollard constructed the first resort on the west end of Donner Lake. Between mid 1864 and early 1868 Pollard’s Station on the Dutch Flat & Donner Lake Wagon Road was office to the Pioneer Stage Co. and Wells, Fargo & Co. Express, as well as a hotel, boasting bar room, reading room, billiards and a bowling alley. Visitors could rent boats, horses or carriages to enjoy the scenic grandeur. The station was ravaged by fire twice and rebuilt once. The station was no longer needed due to the completion of the railroad in June 1868, which put a virtual end to wagon and stage traffic across the Sierra.

name: Schallenberger Cabin Site
address: In Donner Memorial State Park, about 75 yds. east of Museum
mission_description: Near this spot stood a small cabin built by 18-year old Moses Schallenberger and two other men. They were members of the Stephens-Townsend-Murphy party of 1844, the first pioneers to take wagons over the Sierra Nevada, opening the Truckee Route of the California Trail. The three men had volunteered to remain behind and guard six of the wagons left here by the main party. Due to extreme winter weather conditions and lack of food, the three men agreed to separate. The two older men rejoined the wagon party, but due to his weakened physical condition, Moses Schallenberger chose to remain at the cabin. The young man survived for nearly three months alone in the small cabin during the winter of 1844-45 before being rescued. His cabin would later provide shelter for the Breen family, members of the ill-fated Donner Party, who were stranded here in 1846-47. The courage and resolution of Moses Schallenberger during his solitary winter ordeal in this cabin makes him one of the true heroes in the saga of the California Trail. This monument was made possible through the generosity of many groups and individuals committed to the preservation of the California Trail. Note: The monument contains a time capsule to be opened on August 19, 2095.

name: Emigrant Trail on Coldstream Road
address: West side of Cold Stream Rd, 800 ft south of Donner Pass Rd, just past Cold Stream Day Use sign, Truckee
mission_description: The Emigrant Trail in the pioneer days of California turned to the south at this point for approximately three miles, then went across the summit of the Sierras about a mile south of the present railroad. It was here that the Donner Party missed the trail owing to the early snows, resulting in the tragedy.

name: Donner Party - Graves Cabin Site
address: Opposite 12020 Donner Pass Rd in West Truckee
mission_description: Plaque dedicated 1919 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Donner Party 1846-1847. On this spot stood the Graves Cabin.

name: Gateway Cabin
mission_description: This cabin was one of several built by Jack Wolert for Dick Joseph in 1939 on US Route 40. The cabin was constructed of lumber salvaged from houses being dismantled five miles north of Truckee at Hobart Mills and served as the Gateway Motel’s office. Originally located at the site of the current Gateway Shopping Center on Donner Pass Road (historic US 40). It was donated to the Truckee Donner Historical Society in 1990 and moved to this location on May 23, 1991. Thanks to community efforts, the cabin has been restored and serves as a historical research library.

name: Hooligan Rock
address: 11200 Donner Pass Rd, east end of parking lot
mission_description: Behind this broken rock, vigilante justice in the form of a tar and feather party or other form of physical punishment was meted out to the villains and ruffians who plagued Truckee through the dawn of the 20th-century. Constable Jacob Teeter bravely fought against vigilantism and his friend, attorney C. F. McGlashan, blasted the rock, ending its symbolism of terror, and used parts of the rock in a wall around his mansion. His granddaughter, Nona, recalled that the rock formed a 'backdrop of ugly secret scenes, floggings in the night, scalding tar and a smother of feathers, curses and screams for mercy.

name: Sierra Sun (Truckee Republican)
address: 10775 Pioneer Trail, Pioneer Commerce Center, Truckee
mission_description: Oldest continuous business enterprise in the Central Sierra commenced publication in 1869 as the 'Truckee Republican' and was also informally known as the 'Truckee Screwdriver.' The definitive 'History of the Donner Party' was first published in this newspaper in 1879 when author, teacher, statesman C. F. McGlashan was its editor. Note: The Truckee Republican, which began life as the Grass Valley Republican, commenced publishing at Truckee in 1872, not 1869. Its descendant is now the Sierra Sun. The plaque was moved in 2014 from 12315 Deerfield Drive, and cannot currently be located.

name: Donner Camp at Alder Creek Valley
address: Alder Creek Picnic Site; 2.75 m. north of 1-80 on Hwy 89, 0.1 m. east of Hwy 89, Truckee
mission_description: This site has three plaques and was designated a National Historical Landmark in 1966. First plaque dedicated 1996 by Tahoe National Forest: In the fall of 1846, 25 members of the Donner Party became trapped by an early snowstorm here at Alder Creek Valley. The George and Jacob Donner families, their teamsters, and fellow travelers suffered extreme hardship and starvation. They spent the winter here cut off from the rest of their party who camped at Donner Lake. Only eleven survived the ordeal. Their survival, against desperate odds, stands as a testament to the enduring pioneer spirit that helped shape the future of California.Second plaque dedicated 1996 by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus: They gave unselfishly, their fortunes and their lives that their children should survive. Near this site, in the winter of 1846, two pioneer women gave up their lives for their families. Tamsen and Elizabeth Donner feared their many children could not survive the ravages of cold and starvation when the party was caught in an early blizzard. They provided care and comfort to their families and companions throughout the snowbound winter, desperately trying to prevent the death of their loved ones. Both lost their lives. However, most of their children survived to carry their mothers' dreams of new life and new beginnings to the valleys of California. The summit that they never crossed now bears the family name. An inspiration to all who followed their footsteps across the Sierra Nevada Mountains, we herein honor the memory and the sacrifices of these women. Their struggle to survive, enduring hardships we can barely imagine, remains a legacy of the pioneer spirit. On this 150th anniversary of their tragic encampment the Chief Truckee Chapter of E Clampus Vitus dedicates this monument to their spirit and the preservation of their memory that we not forget the sacrifices they made in opening California to its destiny.The Donner Camp Site plaque is located in the middle of the Donner Camp Interpretive Trail, just past the end of the boardwalk.Second plaque dedicated 1960 by Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus, Historical Society, Tahoe National Forest USFS, Truckee-Donner Chamber of Commerce, and Native Daughters of the Golden West: On October 28, 1846 the six covered wagons brought west by George and Jacob Donner and their families halted here for repairs. By March of 1847 one half of the party of 22 adults and children had died of starvation and cold. They came west seeking a new life and found misery and death.

name: Hobart Mills Site
address: Just east of Hwy 89, five miles north of Truckee. There are two plaques, about 200 yards apart
mission_description: First plaque dedicated 1938 by descendants of Walter Scott Hobart is about 0.2 m. north of the junction of Hobart Mills Rd with Old Hwy 89 on west side of Old 89: This monument marks the townsite of Hobart Mills, California. A logging and lumbering enterprise of sixty-six years life in the Sierra Nevada mountains it commemorates and honors its founder Walter Scott Hobart 1839-1892 and those whose loyalty, industry and ability made its successful operation possible.

name: Donner Memorial State Park
address: 12593 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee. In addition to the Museum, the Park contains three monuments.
mission_description: The Origin Of The Park. Joseph Marzen sold one acre of land east of Donner Lake to Charles F. McGlashan for the purpose of erecting a monument to the Donner Party. McGlashan then sold the land to the Native Sons of the Golden West (NSGW) for $1.00 in August of 1909. At the center of the acre, according to McGlashan, was the site of the Breen Cabin, where the monument would be situated. On June 6, 1918, the NSGW dedicated the completed Pioneer Memorial. California Governor William D. Stephens signed legislation acquiring 'Donner Monument and lands contingent thereto.' On May 23, 1928, the Grand Parlor of the Native Sons of the Golden West conveyed eleven acres of land to the People of the State of California. The deed for the parcel adjacent to the Lincoln Highway included one provision: 'The tract of land above described shall be known and designated as the Donner State Monument and shall be a memorial to the California Pioneers of the Overland Trail’. Note: The plaque is inside the building, to the left as you enter.

name: Murphy Cabin
address: In Donner Memorial State Park, a few hundred yds south of Museum on trail
mission_description: The face of this rock formed the north end and the fireplace of the Murphy Cabin. General Stephen W. Kearney, on June 22, 1847, buried under the middle of the cabin the bodies found in the vicinity. Following is a complete list of members of the Donner party who occupied the various cabins and tents.This and the other Donner campsites were designated a National Historical Landmark in 1961. Placed on the National Register.

name: Donner Emigrant Trail
address: Front of Tahoe Truckee High School, 11725  Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
mission_description: The Emigrant Trail in the Pioneer Days of California came through the low pass to the north, facing this monument. The Trail turned west at this point for a distance of twenty-six hundred feet where a tablet describes the route then followed. Adjoining plaque dedicated 2014: First Permanent Emigrant Trail Markers. The nearby monument was envisioned in 1929 by C.F. McGlashan, Truckee’s foremost resident 1872-1931 and author of the 1880 classic, The History of the Donner Party; P.M. Weddell, who placed wooden signs on the Donner Trail from Verdi, Nevada over Coldstream Pass to Lake Mary from 1924 until his death in 1951; and W.F. Knowland, U. S. Senator (1945-1959) and the chairman of The Native Sons of the Golden West’s Landmark Commission. The three trail authorities met in McGlashan’s law office in Truckee to draw up the text for the plaque on this monument, listed as #3 on the 1930 Weddell map to the right and a companion plaque for the monument listed as #5 located one half mile to the west on old Hwy 40 and Coldstream Road. Note: According to the P. M. Weddell map of the Historic Emigrant Road, this resting place of the Native Sons' marker is close to its original location.

name: Hobart Mills Site Second Plaque
mission_description: Walter Scott Hobart's Sierra Nevada Wood & Lumber Company moved machinery, buildings and railroad equipment here from Lake Tahoe in 1896. The town and business flourished for 40 years, ceasing operations in 1936. Fibreboard Corporation operated a mill and railroad here from 1946 to 1955, logging timber purchased from Southern Pacific. The old mill was burned in 1964. Hobart Mills was an important lumbering center and a major contributor to the heritage of the Eastern Sierra.

name: Donner or Pioneer Monument
address: In Donner Memorial State Park, about 100 yds. east of Museum
mission_description: Monument dedicated and first two plaques placed 1918 by the Governors of California and Nevada, three survivors of the Donner Party, and Native Daughters of the Golden West. First plaque: Virile to risk and find, Kindly withal and a ready help. Facing the brunt of fate. Indomitable-unafraid." Second plaque: In commemoration of the pioneers who crossed the plains to settle in California. Landmark registered and third plaque placed 1962 by State of California, CHL 134: Donner Party. Near this spot stood the Breen Cabin of the party of emigrants who started for California from Springfield, Illinois, in April, 1846, under the leadership of Captain George Donner. Delays occurred and when the party reached this locality, on October 29, the Truckee Pass emigrant road was concealed by snow. The height of the shaft of the monument indicates the depth of the snow, which was twenty-two feet. After futile efforts to cross the summit the party was compelled to encamp for the winter. The Graves cabin was situated about three- quarters of a mile to the eastward, the Murphy cabin was about two hundred yards southwest of the monument, and the Donner tents were at the head of Alder Creek. Ninety people were in the party and forty-two perished, most of them from starvation and exposure.

name: Kruger-White House
mission_description: Designated a National Historic Landmark 1982: This property Kruger-White House has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places by the United States Department of the Interior. Note: W. H. Kruger, a lumberman and entrepreneur, built this impressive home 107 years ago. Mr. Kruger contributed significantly to the 19th century community development of Truckee as one of the town's leading commercial pioneers. Mr. C. B. White, a banker, bought the house in 1904. Today, the Kruger-White home stands as an historic architectural landmark in a town which, for over a century, has represented an important gateway to California.

name: Truckee Jail
address: Northeast corner of Spring and Jibboom Sts, Truckee
mission_description: 1875 Old Truckee Jail. Built in September 1875 and in continuous use until 1964. Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1971 by Nevada County, NEV 04: The first extension of the Nevada County jail which was built in 1875 by order of the County Supervisors on the petition of residents in Meadow Lake and Truckee townships due to the high cost of transporting prisoners from the eastern part of the county to the jail in Nevada City. Built of stone at a cost of $2,500 the building housed its first prisoner in September 1875.  Note: Building now houses the Truckee-Donner Historical Museum.

name: Rocking Stone
address: Between High St and Keiser Ave, near Spring St, Truckee
mission_description: A natural glacial formation, or the work of an unknown tribe as a form of altar. Its exact origin will never be known. The perfectly balanced stone until recently would rock at the touch of a finger. C. F. McGlashan built the original tower in 1895 and used it to display Donner Party relics and his famous butterfly collection. Site of an overnight stop for the Olympic Torch in 1960.

name: The Tin Can -- Dot's
mission_description: The two modern buildings replaced structures built in the early 20th-century and used in two of Truckee’s notorious industries: bootlegging and prostitution. They upheld a tradition begun on this street in the 1870’s. Many a thirst was slaked and need fulfilled because of these buildings' contents. Politely ignored, although they never failed because of lack of business, they operated until mid-century to serve the working men of this and surrounding communities. Changing commercial interests and ultimately property values doomed these buildings to history.

name: Old Stone Garage
address: Southwest corner Jibboom and Bridge Sts, Truckee
mission_description: Truckee’s Old Stone Garage and Site of Town’s First Dwelling. In 1863, Joseph Gray built Truckee's first structure on this site for use as the Dutch Flat-Donner Lake Wagon Road's toll station. The old log structure was moved in 1907 to the Englehart property on Church Street, one block east of this site, where it still stands and the Brethren of ECV dedicated a plaque in 1965. In 1909, D. J. Smith, with the help of European-trained stone masons, constructed the present building for use as a livery and garage.

name: Jibboom Street
address: Southwest corner Jibboom and Bridge Sts, Truckee. The stone and bronze plaque have been removed and are awaiting rededication
mission_description: Wooden plaque dedicated and placed in Pastime Club Bar 1969. Bronze plaque rededicated and placed in present location 1979  by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus: Jibboom Street. Sierra Site of the World’s Oldest Profession 1867-1949.

name: Truckee's First Log Cabin
mission_description: First Log Cabin. Erected by Joseph Gray at S.W. corner of present day Bridge and Spring streets to serve Dutch Flat Wagon Road traffic over Donner Pass. Removed to this site 1907.

name: Truckee Round House Site
address: East end of municipal parking lot, just west of 10021 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
mission_description: Needed to house and maintain the engines of the Central Pacific Railroad during construction of the trans-Sierra crossing, an enclosed wooden round house was constructed here in 1868. It was razed by fire in March of 1869. A 16-stall wooden structure was built that year as the maintenance facility of the C.P.R.R., Truckee Division. Another fire in 1876 resulted in construction of a 22-stall granite and wooden structure. This served through 1942, when it was officially retired, a victim of the end of the steam era and consolidation of maintenance at other locations. The round houses were home to helper engines, fire trains and the first rotary snow plow in the Sierra.

name: First Transcontinental Railroad--Truckee
address: Track side of Amtrak station, 10065 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
mission_description: While construction on Sierra tunnels delayed Central Pacific, advance forces at Truckee began building forty miles of track east and west of Truckee, moving all supplies by wagon and sled. Summit Tunnel was opened in December, 1867. The line reached Truckee April 3, 1868, and the Sierra was conquered. Rails reached Reno June 19, and construction advanced eastward one mile daily toward the meeting with Union Pacific at Promontory May 10,1869, to complete the first transcontinental railroad.

name: Theodore Dehone Judah
address: Track side of Amtrak station, 10065 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
mission_description: As Chief Engineer of the Central Pacific Railroad, Judah's engineering skill, political savvy and financial genius, along with the promoters' capital, culminated in the formation and construction of the Trans-Sierra leg of the first transcontinental railroad. While fighting the excesses of the railroadÍs promoters, he died without seeing his dream completed.

name: Truckee Flag Pole
address: 10065 Donner Pass Rd, northwest side of Amtrak station, Truckee
mission_description: Truckee / Jewel of the Eastern Sierras. First known as Gray's Toll Station, then Coburn's Station, Truckee was established in 1863. Renowned for its lumber industry, transcontinental railroad, icehouses, saloons and red light district, Truckee has never been known for her laid back demeanor. It has always been a town where people came to entertain themselves on Friday and Saturday nights, just as it is today. Second plaque dedicated 1994 by Truckee Fire Protection District: Truckee Fire Protection District. This flagpole represents 100 years of service by the Truckee Fire Protection District and its members, past and present for their commitment to the preservation of life and property.

name: Old Capitol Building
mission_description: The Old Capitol. Erected in 1870. In its heyday it was the social center of Truckee . . . Many of the leading thespians . . . politicians . . . and other celebrities of that era gathered here . . . Note: This plaque has disappeared. A plaque placed on the front of building by unknown persons reads: Capitol Building 1870 Truckee California. The first brick building in Truckee, it was originally Hurd's Saloon, then the Capitol Saloon, later used by the Piper Opera Company and the County Court.

name: Truckee's Vigilance ("601") Committee
address: On sidewalk in front of 10096 Donner Pass Rd, across street from Amtrak Station, Truckee
mission_description: Truckee’s vigilance committee, known as the 601, was born in response to the rise in crime and 'undesirables' which plagued the young railroad town. In late 1874 and early 1875, the 601 carried out a campaign to intimidate and rid the town of those elements. After accidentally shooting one of their own members, the 601 disbanded until August 1889 when they reassembled for one last time. Though their goals were never fully achieved, the 601 did bring a semblance of law and order to the area through their vigilance.

name: George Schaffer
address: Star Hotel, 10015 West River St. Truckee
mission_description: One of Truckee’s earliest settlers, Schaffer in 1866 built the first lumber mill in the town. He freighted the locomotive 'San Mateo' to Truckee in a winter crossing of the Sierra prior to the laying of Central Pacific tracks. This building 'The Star Hotel' was built by Schaffer probably for his family. When mill operations were relocated up Martis Creek in 1871, this building was converted to a hotel and has remained in continuous operation to this day. For 24 years, the Truckee Basin supplied timber to railroads, mines and boom towns through 'Uncle George's' enterprises. Note: The Schaffer family cemetery, located at 10233 Schaffer Dr., may be visited by the public.

name: Old Chinese Herb Shop
address: Corner of S.E. River St. and Brockway Rd., Truckee
mission_description: Old Chinatown. Construction of the Central Pacific Railroad over Donner Summit brought thousands of Chinese laborers here in 1868. They used ‘squatter's rights' to build a ramshackle colony along the Truckee River on what is now River Avenue East. A huge fire destroyed Chinatown on May 29, 1875, but the Orientals rebuilt their community. Finally, on Nov. 18, 1878, a group of about 500 citizens, under the leadership of the Caucasian League, tore down the shanty town and ordered the 1000 or more Chinese to leave. They simply moved across the river, adjoining this former site of a Chinese herb shop, and built anew. A third fire, on Jan. 3, 1883, consumed the 'new' Chinatown and brought about the gradual end to the Chinese colony here. Bronze plaque dedicated 1980 by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus. Text of bronze plaque: Old Chinese Herb Shop.

name: Chief Truckee
address: Truckee River Regional Park, Hwy. 267, 1 m. south of Truckee
mission_description: Chief Truckee. The legendary Paiute leader; friend and guide to pioneers; breveted a 'Captain' by John C. Fremont; gave his name to this valley, river and town; died near Dayton, Nevada, in 1860.

name: Sierra Mountain Cemetery
address: East end of E. Jibboom St, Truckee
mission_description: The Masonic and Odd Fellows lodges each established cemeteries here in 1869 or 1870 to provide a burial place for their deceased. Catholics established a cemetery to the southwest. Pioneers and prominent citizens were buried within the original cemetery grounds. The less reputable were buried outside the fences. Stories abound of the bodies placed in snowbanks or ice houses awaiting the ground thaw. The Truckee Cemetery District was formed in 1946 and received title to the land and named the cemetery in 1964. In 1954 the original site increased in size despite the best efforts of the community to prevent the townfolk from dying.

name: Victory Highway Monument
address: Northwest corner of Spring St and Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
mission_description: First plaque dedicated 1928. Text of plaque: Dedicated to California’s sons and daughters who served their country in the World War 1917-1918 and to the memory of those who gave the last full measure of devotion. Second plaque and monument dedicated 1998 by Truckee Town Council and California Department of Transportation: Victory Highway Monument Rededication July 24, 1998. This monument was originally sited on old Highway 40 near the California/Nevada line in 1928 and removed in the mid 1970s due to vandalism. It was one of a series of monuments placed on the 'Victory Highway' across the U.S., honoring those who died serving the United States in World War I. Donner Pass Road and part of Glenshire Drive through Truckee still follow the basic alignment of the old highway. The Town of Truckee, in cooperation with CalTrans, has rededicated this monument not only for its original purpose and the history of Old Highway 40, but also for current revitalization efforts occurring in historic downtown Truckee.

name: Commercial Row / Brickelltown Historic District
mission_description: The Commercial Row/ Brickelltown Historic District lies in the center of Truckee along the tracks of the first transcontinental railroad. It includes the first built areas of Truckee. Because of fires, most of the buildings in the district range from 1870 to the 1920s. The district illustrates Truckee's relationship with the railroad and the lumber industry and Truckee's appearance more than 100-years ago. Truckee was originally called Coburn Station, and then renamed around 1868 after a Paiute chief. The District was dedicated in 2009 by the Truckee Town Council.

name: Lake Tahoe Railway & Transportation Company Site
address: Just east of 10130 W. River St, across the railroad tracks from Amtrak station. The plaque is missing. If you have any information about its whereabouts, please contact the publisher.
mission_description: The Lake Tahoe Railway & Transportation Company was incorporated on December 1898 by Duane Leroy Bliss. The Narrow Gauge Railroad opened for seasonal traffic on May 1, 1900. The line ran from the Southern Pacific Depot in Truckee, 15 miles south to the shores of Lake Tahoe. Tahoe City hosted the railroad’s shops. The Tahoe Tavern hotel and pier where the train met the Bliss steamer - Tahoe. Southern Pacific Purchased the line and converted it to standard gauge in 1926. Passenger Service operated until abandonment in November 1943.

name: Stampede Circle of Stones
address: 10600 Brockway Rd, northeast corner of Truckee River Regional Park, Truckee
mission_description: The Stampede Circle of Stones is the oldest manmade structure in the Truckee region-at least 500 years old. Built by the Washoe or their predecessors, the Martis people, the Circle's original home was in Stampede Valley, about 10 miles northeast of here. In 1969 it was moved to this location shortly before the construction of the Stampede Dam flooded the valley. Archaeological digging on the original site indicates it may have been used as an antelope corral.

name: Boca Dam - Newlands Reclamation Project
address: East end of Boca Dam, Stampede Road 1 m. north of I-80, about 5 m. east of Truckee
mission_description: Designated a National Historic Landmark 1981: Boca Dam 1937-1940. United States Department of the Interior, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary; Bureau of Reclamation, John C. Page, Commissioner; R. F. Walter, Chief Engineer; L. J. Foster and C. S. Hale, Construction Engineers. Height 116 feet, Length 1629 feet, Storage capacity 40,901 acre-feet. Contractor, George W. Condon Co. Note: Originally called the Truckee-Carson Project, the Newlands Project covers a large area in western Nevada and a smaller area of Truckee-Tahoe area. One of five authorized by the Federal Reclamation Act of 1902, to reclaim arid lands for agricultural purposes. Renamed in 1919 in honor of U.S. Senator Francis G. Newlands of Nevada, water from natural flow and storage in Lake Tahoe and Boca Reservoir is diverted from Truckee River into the 32.5-mile Truckee Canal and then discharged into the Carson River.

name: Boca Brewery
address: East end of Boca Dam, 1 m. north of 1-80 on Stampede Rd, about 5 m. east of Truckee
mission_description: Boca. Noted as a railroad, ice and lumbering center since 1867 but most fondly remembered and hereby honored as home of the Boca Brewery which was located 1/2 mile south of this point across the Truckee River. Boca Lager Beer was world famous and mercifully slaked the thirst of a grateful mankind. Second plaque placed 2001 by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus: Boca Beer. Warranted to keep in any weather.

name: Boca Ice Harvest Site
address: Stampede Rd, 2 m. north of 1-80, 5 m. east of Truckee
mission_description: From 1868 to 1927 huge quantities of ice were harvested from the Truckee Basin. This provided employment and significantly contributed to the area’s economic growth and its colorful history. Boca Pond was one of the first to be used to harvest ice and ship it across the nation. It was one of the last of the ice plants to survive competition from artificial ice companies.

name: Clinton Narrow Gauge Railroad
address: Southeast corner of Hirschdale Rd, and Juniper Way, about 5 m. east of Truckee and 1 m. south of I-80
mission_description: First steam railroad logging operation in the Truckee River Basin. Commenced operation in the late 1870’s under the supervision of Fred Burckhalter, head of the Pacific Lumber and Wood Co. Line extended 10 miles along Juniper Creek with hope of eventual service to Lake Tahoe. Line abandoned in 1901 after several conflagrations at the PL&W Co. mill in Clinton.

name: Floriston (Bronco Site)
address: Eastbound Floriston offramp on I-80 east of Truckee
mission_description: Established in 1872 as Bronco, this railroad wood stop became a noted ice and lumber center and was renamed in 1891. The Floriston Pulp and Paper Company built the present town after 1899 and operated one of the worldÍs largest pulp mills through 1930. Its paper products and ice helped California’s agricultural industry feed the hungry of the world. Note: Drive through culvert tunnel to get to town, which still has the feel of a company town.

layer: Performance Spaces in Nevada County California
name: Art Truckee
mission_description: Art Gallery, Performance and Event Venue, Wine Bar

layer: Performance Spaces in Nevada County California
name: Center for the Arts
mission_description: The Center for the Arts is a cultural and educational organization that promotes and presents the literary, visual, and performing arts for the enrichment of our community.

layer: Performance Spaces in Nevada County California
name: Community Arts Center
mission_description: Our auditorium at the CAC is well-equipped for your next public or private event. Features include a large stage, theatrical lighting, and live audio production equipment. You can also project films or other media content to a full-size cinema screen, the only one in Truckee!

mission_description: Located in Grass Valley, California, the Nevada County Fairgrounds has been declared as  California's Most Beautiful Fairgrounds, and is covered with hundreds of towering pine trees on almost 90 acres. It is home to the annual Nevada County Fair, the Draft Horse Classic, the Country Christmas Faire, world-class music festivals, and year-round community events. mission_description: The North Columbia Schoolhouse Cultural Center gives the rural San Juan Ridge community a local place to meet, to share its creativity, and to participate in a wide variety of enriching activities. The North Star House is listed on the National and State Registers of Historic Places. It is located on a portion of the former North Star Mine, a 14-acre site of spectacular Gold Country landscapes. The North Star House is owned, operated and being lovingly restored by the North Star Historic Conservancy, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization.
