name: Word after Word Books
mission_description: Word After Word Books is a welcoming space for the community and visitors to connect around books. We carry titles by local authors, regional and history books about the area, and books and magazines pertaining to the outdoor lifestyle in our community. We also have the latest bestsellers and favorite staff picks. There is a section for children and young adults, the Kids & Teens Corner, with comfy beanbag chairs. The Word After Word Team hosts author events, writing workshops, book clubs, and story times.

name: Bear Yuba Land Trust
mission_description: Bear Yuba Land Trust is a private, non profit, membership supported organization that works to promote voluntary conservation of the region’s natural, historical and agricultural legacy. The Land Trust provides a lasting community heritage by protecting and enhancing meadows, watersheds, forests, farms and ranches, trails and parks.  BYLT exists to create a balance between nature and the needs of people like you who make a life and a livelihood here.  Our mission is to enrich your deep community connection with the land  today, tomorrow, and forever.

name: C A T T Community Project
mission_description: CATT Community Project is a 501c(3) non profit, charitable organization established in October 1999 as a sponsored arm of the Contractors Association of Truckee Tahoe. CATT Community Project is governed by a 10 member Board of Directors which meets monthly. CATT Community Project provides design and construction assistance to other non profits and governmental agencies as a way of giving back to the community.

name: City of Grass Valley Historical Commission
mission_description: It is the intent of the City to encourage the preservation of the City's historical and architecturally significant resources by the formation of a Historical Commission which has the duty and function to identify and designate historical properties within the City and to honor those property owners who have maintained or restored these historical properties.

name: Daughters of the American Revolution – Capt. John Oldham Chapter
mission_description: The DAR, founded in 1890 and headquartered in Washington, DC is a non profit, non-political, volunteer women's service organization dedicated to promoting patriotism, preserving American history, and securing America's future through better education for children.

name: Donner Summit Historical Society
mission_description: Donner Summit Historical Society is dedicated to telling the story of the most important historical square mile in California and maybe the entire Western U.S. We operate a museum on the Summit as well as the 20 Mile Museum along Old Highway 40.

name: Empire Mine Park Association
mission_description: Empire Mine Park Association (EMPA) is dedicated to maintaining the history, beauty and worldwide appeal of Empire Mine State Historic Park.   Founded in 1976, our goal is to make each visit authentic, safe and memorable.   We’re a 501(c)(3) non profit organization, and we provide the Park with vital financial support to continue its legacy of gold, grit, and glory.

name: Gold Country Celtic Society
mission_description: The Gold Country Celtic Society was organized to celebrate the culture of these proud people, many of whom, especially the Cornish and Welsh, worked the hard rock mines and made our Nevada City Grass Valley area famous. The Society wishes to perpetuate Celtic traditions of music, dance,language, and costume.

name: Mountain Area Preservation Foundation
mission_description: To preserve the Truckee Tahoe region’s mountain character and natural environment for present and future generations.

name: Nevada Cemetery District
mission_description: The Nevada Cemetery District is an independent special district charged with providing respectful and cost effective interment services appropriate for the diversity of local conditions and circumstances. It is responsible for the improvement, expansion and operation of public cemeteries in Western Nevada County, including historic cemeteries established by fraternal, pioneer, religious, social and other organizations

name: Nevada City Rancheria of the Nisenan Tribe
mission_description: The Nevada City Rancheria was created from an executive order by President Woodrow Wilson in 1913 from a land allotment obtained by Chief Charlie Cully in 1887. Cully's land on Cement Hill became Federal Trust Land and the Tribal government became a federally recognized entity. The Nevada City Rancheria was one of 48 Rancherias illegally terminated in the 1950s and 1960s by the California Rancheria Termination Acts. Most have been restored; the Nevada City Nisenan Rancheria has not. Yet.

name: Nevada County Cultural Preservation Trust
mission_description: The Miners Foundry Cultural Center is a living historic treasure serving Nevada County as a cultural arts and community events center. More than a venue, the nonprofit’s mission is to preserve, enhance and utilize the historic Miners Foundry for cultural, educational and social activities in Nevada County. It is a symbol of California’s rich historical heritage, providing an educational and social bridge from our past to the present and future.

name: Nevada County Gem & Mineral Society

To encourage the collection of minerals and gems. To foster the study and practice of the lapidary arts.  To provide field trips to mineral localities.  To promote good fellowship, education and recreation.

name: Nevada County Historical Society
mission_description: The Nevada County Historical Society had its beginning in the fall of 1944 after being inspired by Dr. Robert E. Burns, President of the College of the Pacific. The objective of the new organization was to preserve every source of Nevada County history. Monthly programs were planned to entertain and educate members, and the committee chairmen and groups formed the foundation of the society by collecting, displaying, and preserving the memorabilia of the county.

name: Nevada Theatre Commission

name: The Sierra Fund

name: Truckee Donner Historical Society

Besides maintaining the historic Joseph Research Cabin (the Gateway Cabin), the Society is also responsible for operating the Old Jail Museum which was built in 1875.  The Society maintains the Community Memorial Garden including the Memorial Arch behind the Old Jail Museum, the Donner  Cross, and Schaffer Cemetery.

name: "Community As Ecosystem"
mission_description: Artists: Sara L. Smith, Toni Standteiner/Mountain Forge.  Commissioned by the TRDRPD, 'думCommunity As Ecosystem" main mural image measures more than 11 ft. high by 16 ft. wide.  The piece celebrates Truckee's new Aquatic Center donors. The artists represent the concept of joyful balance noting each donor (no matter level of contribution) is a vital part of the overall effort.  The mural speaks to the wider concept of community as an ecosystem, and reminds us that we are all essential. The artists note: "The mural is painted using sepia tones to tie us back to our past, and is painted upon a wall created with reclaimed Lake Tahoe pier wood, creating a tangible tie to our physical past and present.  It depicts a stylized image of Martis Valleyду»s diverse natural environment, and donors are represented by a combination of cut and manipulated animal shapes and forged iron environmental elements, such as mountain peaks, cattails and wave forms in the creek.  On a separate panel each and every donorду»s name has been hand lettered, grouped next to its corresponding donor category and animal shape.дуќ In addition two additional small panels were created to specifically recognize the individuals who helped shepherd the project to fruition, and well as the organizations that contributed multi-million dollar grant funds.

name: "Aspen Grove" in Radiation Lobby at Tahoe Forest Cancer Center
mission_description: Artist: Troy Corliss.  The colorful array of glass leaves in the Troy Corliss думAspen Groveдуќ welcomes patients and visitors to the Radiation Therapy waiting space. Fabricated in steel and kiln fused glass, the artwork integrates an experience of the natural world with interior architecture. The gentle curves of the tree trunks and the subtle patterning and warm colors of the glass leaves creates a three dimensional design that is both intriguing and calming. The Grove can be experienced as a powerful whole at first sight or explored with interest with repeated visits.
